page.title: Gesellschaft zur Verfolgung von Urheberrechtsverletzungen e.V.

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Society for the Prosecution of Copyright Infringement | native_name = GVU - Gesellschaft zur Verfolgung von Urheberrechtsverletzungen e.V. | logo = [[File:Gesellschaft zur Verfolgung von Urheberrechtsverletzungen (logo).svg|300px|Official Workmark of the GVU]] | type = Registered Association | foundation = Berlin, Germany ({{Start date|1985|02|27}}) | location_city = [[Berlin]] | location_country = Germany | key_people = Vincent de la Tour ([[Chairman]]),
Matthias Leonardy ([[Managing Director]]) | industry = Movies and Games | homepage = [http://www.gvu.de/ www.gvu.de] }} The '''Gesellschaft zur Verfolgung von Urheberrechtsverletzungen e.V.''' (GVU, Society for the Prosecution of Copyright Infringement) is a registered association under German law. According to its own description it works for the [[Video game industry|game]] and [[film industry]] and helps to protect [[intellectual property]] and to counter the illegal distribution of [[Copyright infringement|copied materials]]. For this purpose, the association cooperates with the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA).{{cite web | url = http://mpaa.org/about/around-the-world | title = Around the World | publisher = Motion Picture Association of America | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} The GVU was founded in the spring of 1984 and entered the register of associations in February 1985 for the first time. The headquarters were located first in [[Hamburg]], since 2008 they have been in [[Mitte (locality)|Berlin-Mitte]]. The GVU became known to a wider public by participating in campaigns such as "pirates are criminals“ and investigations in the Kino.to case.{{cite web | title = European Police Shut Down Internet Pirate Kino.to | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/european-police-shut-down-internet-196223 | publisher = The Hollywood Reporter | author = Scott Roxborough | date = 2011-08-06 | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} == History == [[File:ZentraleGVU.jpg|300px|thumbnail|Headquarters in Berlin (Quarter Mitte)]] === Early Years === Against the backdrop of a rapidly increasing demand for movies on [[VHS]] and an increase in [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]] at the same time, film industry representatives agreed in early 1984 to set up a separate company to combat illegal distribution of [[copyright]]ed material. The decision was primarily driven by the motivation of the industry, to detach from the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI). The longtime chairman of the Bundesverband Audiovisuelle Medien (BVV, Federal Association of Audiovisual Media) and Managing Director of the German subsidiary of [[Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment]], Bodo Schwartz, was key in the establishment of GVU. The establishment of the GVU as a [[Business entity|legally registered association]] was formally announced in the autumn of 1984 at the [[High fidelity|HiFi]] trade fair in Düsseldorf. The first constitution was adopted on December 17, 1984. It first entered the register of the city of Hamburg on February 27, 1985, finalising the establishment of the association on that day.{{cite web | url = https://www.handelsregister.de/rp_web/welcome.do?language=en | title = Common register portal of the German federal states | publisher = Amtsgericht Hagen | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} Next to Bodo Schwartz, Paul Miller of the [[Cinema International Corporation]] (CIC) and Manfred Goller of the Verband der Filmverleiher (VDF, Association of Film Distributors) were members of the founding board. === Software Era === After exclusive funding of the GVU by the movie industry in its initial years, the organisations range of tasks expanded in 1997 to include [[PC game|computer games]]. On the one hand this was due to the parallels between illegal copies of films and games - both in the production and distribution - and on the other hand, the simpler distribution of unauthorized material over the emerging [[Internet]]. [[Sony Computer Entertainment]]’s membership of the GVU in 1997 initiated the membership of the entire Entertainment Software Association in the GVU in the following year.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/241.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807142341/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/241.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-08-07 |title=Milestones of our Work |publisher=GVU |date=2007-04-03 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |format=PDF |language=German }} In 2000, [[Microsoft]] entered the GVU as the first member of the [[software industry]], which represented a significant milestone for the work of the GVU and directed the attention of the general public to the association. Simultaneously, this resulted in an expansion of the range of GVU’s tasks. As early as in 2001, the GVU took over the [[Management|administration]] of the organization SAFE, which is responsible for the fight against [[copyright infringement]] in [[Switzerland]]. At the same time, cooperation intensified with the [[Austria]]n Verein für Anti-Piraterie (VAP, Association for Anti-Piracy) in the film and video industry, so the entire [[German language|German-speaking]] area was fully covered. === Management === The statutes of the GVU provides that the [[Vorstand|board]] consists of a chairman and at least three others. The GVU is represented jointly by at least two board members. Currently (as of November 2012) the committee includes Vincent de La Tour (Chairman), Dr. Holger Ensslin, Violetta Psofiou, Ralph Tübben, Alexander Skipis and Dr. Bernd Fakesch.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/17_Impressum.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130211040202/http://www.gvu.de/17_Impressum.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-11 |title=Imprint on the Official Website |publisher=GVU |language=German |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} According to the [[List of company registers|Commercial Register]] there are committees for finance, legal and technology. Next to the executive board the association has a full-time [[general manager|executive director]] who is responsible for the daily operations and reports to the Board. Dr. Matthias Leonardy currently holds this position, who previously worked as a [[Syndic|general counsel]] for the German [[eBay]] Group.{{cite web|url=http://de.linkedin.com/pub/matthias-leonardy/0/668/a40 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121225201307/http://de.linkedin.com/pub/matthias-leonardy/0/668/a40 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-12-25 |title=Professional Profile of Matthias Leonardy |publisher=LinkedIn |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} Work and structure of the GVU was mainly characterized by Bodo Schwartz, who was on the executive board for over 20 years and led it as Chairman for a long time. He also represented the GVU to media and shaped the image of the association in the public, including through various interviews. Schwartz retired from his position of CEO of [[Twentieth Century Fox]] in 2002, and retired from the GVU in October 2006. His retirement speech in late January 2007 was held by [[Sabine Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger]].{{cite web | title = Speech at the New Year Reception of the GVU | date = 2009-08-25 | accessdate = 2011-12-23 | language = German | publisher = FDP Bayern}} == Members == In 2011, a total of about 50 companies and organizations were represented as a member of the GVU. In the field of film this includes virtually all major [[Hollywood]] studios, such as [[Sony Pictures]], [[Twentieth Century Fox]], [[Paramount Pictures]], [[Warner Bros.]] and [[The Walt Disney Studios (production company)|Walt Disney Studios]]. Members from the gaming industry include [[Ubisoft]], Microsoft, [[Activision]], [[Konami]] and [[Koch Media]] as well as respective affiliates of the major film studios. In addition, in its Annual Report 2011, the service providers [[arvato]], [[Cinram]], [[OpSec]] and [[Rovi]] got quoted as members.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/828.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907051457/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/828.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-07 |title=Annual Report 2011 |publisher=GVU |language=German |format=PDF |date=2012-04-25 |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} A special role is played by the membership of numerous [[Trade association|professional organizations]], in which the interests and positions of certain industries are bundled. So for example currently the [[Bundesverband Musikindustrie]] (BVMI, Federal Association of Music Industry), the [[Bundesverband Informationswirtschaft, Telekommunikation und neue Medien]] (BITKOM, German Association for Information Technology, Telecommunications and New Media) and the [[Bundesverband Interaktive Unterhaltungssoftware]] (BIU, Federal Association of Interactive Entertainment Software) belong to the GVU. The [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA), one of the foremost organizations against [[copyright infringement]] in the [[English language|English speaking world]], is a full member too. Overall, in 2011, nine organizations, 21 films- and 15 games providers and five other companies supported the GVU. Over the last five years the number of members has remained largely constant. However, as a result of the economic and [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|financial crisis]], the association lost some companies from the movie industry. The most prominent example in this case is the production and distribution company [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], which in 2007 was still listed as a member of the GVU, but no longer in the following year. MGM went into administration in 2010 and withdrew from other industry associations. Since 2007, the GVU has published annually a list of its members.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/408.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812185131/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/408.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-08-12 |title=Annual Report 2007 |publisher=GVU |format=PDF |language=German |date=2008-06-18 |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} Organizations and [[business|companies]] indirectly involved in the GVU through third-party associations are not explicitly listed in it. Colors = id:lightgrey value:gray(0.9) id:darkgrey value:gray(0.8) id:sfondo value:rgb(1,1,1) id:barra value:rgb(0.6,0.7,0.8) ImageSize = width:500 height:300 PlotArea = left:50 bottom:50 top:30 right:30 DateFormat = x.y Period = from:0 till:60 TimeAxis = orientation:vertical AlignBars = justify ScaleMajor = gridcolor:darkgrey increment:30 start:0 ScaleMinor = gridcolor:lightgrey increment:6 start:0 BackgroundColors = canvas:sfondo BarData = bar:2007 text:2007 bar:2008 text:2008 bar:2009 text:2009 bar:2010 text:2010 bar:2011 text:2011 PlotData = color:barra width:30 align:left bar:2007 from: 0 till:49 bar:2008 from: 0 till:48 bar:2009 from: 0 till:45 bar:2010 from: 0 till:48 bar:2011 from: 0 till:50 PlotData = bar:2007 at:49 fontsize:S text: 49 shift:(-8,5) bar:2008 at:48 fontsize:S text: 48 shift:(-8,5) bar:2009 at:45 fontsize:S text: 45 shift:(-8,5) bar:2010 at:48 fontsize:S text: 48 shift:(-8,5) bar:2011 at:50 fontsize:S text: 50 shift:(-8,5) TextData = fontsize:M pos:(20,10) text:Membership Statistics of the GVU according to Official Notice == Activities == The activities of the Association focuses on preventing economic losses of its members, resulting from unauthorized copying and its dissemination.{{cite web|url=http://www.din.de/sixcms_upload/media/2896/TMC_Leonardy.pdf |title=Digital IP Theft: What it is, its Economics and Effects – and then, what? |author=Matthias Leonardy |publisher=5th Transatlantic Market Conference |date=2011-11-02 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402090428/http://www.din.de/sixcms_upload/media/2896/TMC_Leonardy.pdf |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }} The GVU estimated the loss at several hundred million euros annually. In addition to those defined in the constitution, the association based its efforts primarily on copyright law. === Investigations === The association applies a large part of its resources to the actual detection of copyright infringements. The action is driven by the view that government agencies alone cannot monitor the entire [[Market (economics)|market]] for unlicensed content, which is why the GVU tries to fill this gap. The employees of the GVU, including former [[police officers]] and [[commissioners]], systematically scour the relevant sources of illegal copies, especially on the Internet. Unlike other organizations, by its own admission the GVU does not primarily aim at end-consumers, rather, it targets mainly the "big fishes". Besides those people who for example record a movie at the cinema or make copies from a computer game, these increasingly include the operators of so-called [[BitTorrent|Trackers]].{{cite web|language=German |url=http://www.gvu.de/26_Illegale_Kopien.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070531164334/http://www.gvu.de/26_Illegale_Kopien.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-05-31 |title=Mission and Activities - Disseminating Illegal Copies |publisher=GVU |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} The GVU mainly focuses on large, internationally active [[Warez group|release groups]] where copyrighted products are reproduced and distributed systematically, especially for profit. In its work, the association - if possible - accesses to public registers, for example, to reveal the real people behind a [[Shell corporation|shell company]]. Due of their private-sector activity, the GVU may not identify IP addresses directly. Instead the association directs this as evidence to the relevant authorities. This is usually done as part of criminal procedure, which then leads to public prosecutorial investigations. Unless a criminal procedure is actually opened, an employee of the association often act as an [[expert witness]]. Not every [[complaint]] will automatically lead to a successful prosecution, for example the GVU had to make a total of three applications in the case of Kino.to.{{cite web | url = http://www.netzwelt.de/news/87476-interview-gvu-war-bereits-dritte-strafantrag-gegen-kino-to.html | title = This was the third complaint against kino.to | publisher = Netzwelt | author = Markus Franz | date = 2011-07-10 | accessdate = 2011-12-23 | language = German}} As far as it is known to date, the GVU does not claim [[damages]] from [[warez]] users according to civil law. Instead the association allows its members the freedom to make possible claims for losses incurred. However, the association engages in strongly communicating its legal opinion in individual cases. Particularly in cases related to so-called illegal [[streaming media|streaming]] of copied content, many legal assessments and opinions remain debatable. === Public Relations === In addition to its investigative activities the GVU does intensive public relations, which aims to raise awareness of copyright infringement. In the years 2009 to 2011 members of the association participated in nearly 100 events and reached about 2.000 participants through their [[Presentation|speeches]]. In addition, since the late 80s the GVU has offered seminars for police officers and prosecutors, where they can learn about the consequences of [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]] as well as the activities of the association. In 1990, the GVU launched a prevention program on the topic of [[holography]], a technology making it easier for [[retail]]ers and [[consumer]]s to identify unauthorized copied media. In addition, the association was known to a wider audience through the campaign "Pirates are criminals". This was produced by a subsidiary of the Central Association of German Film Theatres, where the GVU sits on the advisory board. During the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|World Cup 2006]] an action of the umbrella organization MPAA was supported by [[Pelé]].{{cite web | url = http://www.afterdawn.com/news/article.cfm/2006/06/10/mpaa_enlists_football_legend_pel_in_piracy_fight | title = MPAA enlists football legend Pelé in piracy fight | author = James Delahunty | publisher = AfterDawn | date = 2006-06-10 | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} Since 2008, the GVU has performed annually the so-called ROOF-industry forum together with VAP and SAFE, which recently took place in the Kalkscheune venue in Berlin.{{cite web | url = http://irights.info/blog/arbeit2.0/2011/11/22/5-dach-branchenforum-gvu-verkundet-neue-strategie-vielleicht/ | title = GVU announces new strategy - perhaps? | publisher = iRights | date = 2011-11-22 | accessdate = 2011-12-23 | language = German}} At the event, [[Jurist|lawyers]], representatives of the games and movie industries are brought together with trade associations and [[Advocacy group|other stakeholders]] under the slogan "prevention and education". In 2011, the study of digital content usage (short DCN study) received large attention, since it was the first to cover the specific uses of legal and illegal online content. The study was prepared by the GVU and the Bundesverband Musikindustrie (Federal Association of Music Industry) as well as the [[Börsenverein des Deutschen Buchhandels]] (Association of German Book Trade). === Political Influence === Beside the main activities, GVU also gives advice to politicians and represents its interests there. For example, the association - as well as others around the globe - requested a [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]] warning. This should be presented to an Internet user as soon as it first wants to call a pirated copy, but this remains controversial in [[Germany]]. In the course of this particular position, the GVU criticized the [[Federal Ministry of Justice (Germany)|Federal Ministry of Justice]]. Furthermore, the association has complained for years that in case of copyright infringement there is a right of access to Internet service providers, but this would fail due to the lack of storage of communication data ("web problem"). The GVU also calls to execute the missing third basket of the reform of copyright law at last. Likewise, the trend towards trivialisation of copyright infringement by individual politicians criticized repeatedly, most recently in an article by [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] and [[Paul van Dyk]] in TIME. == Proceedings == The investigations conducted by the association were influenced by [[Technological change|technological progress]] over the years: After the beginning of the 80s the fight against pirated VHS tapes were in the spotlight, many prosecutions in the 90s and the following years related to the distribution of movies and games via [[Peer-to-Peer|P2P networks]]. Since 2010 streaming has taken an increasingly larger space.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/798.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128005349/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/798.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-11-28 |title=Annual Report 2009 |publisher=GVU |date=2011-11-22 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |format=PDF |language=German }} The number of cases opened in the years 2007 to 2011 fell from 576 to 204. The decrease is mainly due to the fact that since 2008 many [[State's attorney|prosecutors]] have focused on those investigations in which more than 200 [[Reproduction|copies]] of a work were produced. The GVU in its own words has adopted this trend and focuses its investigative activities increasingly on major cases. In addition to the operations that stern directly from GVU investigations, the association supports those proceedings initiated by the relevant legal authorities. In addition, each year several proceedings are officially reported, which were initiated jointly by [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement agencies]] and the GVU. About a quarter of all cases result in a [[Sentence (law)|verdict]] or penalty order. Colors = id:lightgrey value:gray(0.9) id:darkgrey value:gray(0.8) id:sfondo value:rgb(1,1,1) id:barra value:rgb(0.6,0.7,0.8) ImageSize = width:500 height:300 PlotArea = left:50 bottom:50 top:30 right:30 DateFormat = x.y Period = from:0 till:700 TimeAxis = orientation:vertical AlignBars = justify ScaleMajor = gridcolor:darkgrey increment:350 start:0 ScaleMinor = gridcolor:lightgrey increment:70 start:0 BackgroundColors = canvas:sfondo BarData = bar:2007 text:2007 bar:2008 text:2008 bar:2009 text:2009 bar:2010 text:2010 bar:2011 text:2011 PlotData = color:barra width:30 align:left bar:2007 from: 0 till:576 bar:2008 from: 0 till:221 bar:2009 from: 0 till:223 bar:2010 from: 0 till:213 bar:2011 from: 0 till:204 PlotData = bar:2007 at:576 fontsize:S text: 576 shift:(-8,5) bar:2008 at:221 fontsize:S text: 221 shift:(-8,5) bar:2009 at:223 fontsize:S text: 223 shift:(-8,5) bar:2010 at:213 fontsize:S text: 213 shift:(-8,5) bar:2011 at:204 fontsize:S text: 204 shift:(-8,5) TextData = fontsize:M pos:(20,10) text:Initiated Proceedings of GVU according to Official Notice === Significant Cases === In recent years, the GVU has uncovered many release groups and other networks, some of which stand out because of their size or importance. Especially if in the course of the investigation a [[Search and seizure|house search]] takes place, the respective cases and the activities of the association experienced increased media attention. Mentioned in the annual reports of the GVU important procedures include the following: * In September 2007, 50 properties were searched simultaneously in [[Germany]], the [[Netherlands]], [[France]] and [[Belgium]]. The aim of the objective, which was launched by the GVU project "autumn storms", was primarily to obtain evidence. According to media reports, a total of 60 [[Personal computer|computers]] and 15 [[Hard disk drive|hard drives]] were seized. The GVU itself evaluates the action a success, for example by "[[Keinohrhasen]]" was no unauthorized copy in circulation until 2007. * Also in the same year a person could be found who was responsible for the spread of so-called First seeding the first illegal version of "[[Spider-Man 3|Spiderman 3]]". The person was also senior member of a release group that was responsible for numerous other software [[Copyright infringement#"Piracy"|"piracy"]]. * In March 2008, a request by the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]] umbrella organization caused that the GVU has started investigations against the operator of an internet portal, that offered primarily latest films like "[[Rush Hour 3]]". In the course of the proceedings it became clear that behind the offer stood a broad network, which had connections to the [[United States|U.S.]] and [[Australia]]. Following a criminal complaint of the GVU the [[Frankfurt]] [[Kriminalpolizei|Criminal Police]] confiscated ten servers of the group, which were hosted there in one [[data center|datacenter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/586.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091230033113/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/586.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-12-30 |title=Annual Report 2008 |publisher=GVU |language=German |format=PDF |date=2009-11-16 |accessdate=2011-12-23 }} * Earlier this year, the GVU acted against a Payserver-ring that gave users access to pirated copies for a fee. In this case 13 [[Byte|terabytes]] of data were provided for a total of more than 10,000 registered users. In addition the association led a criminal conduct against operators of so-called trackers in [[BitTorrent]] network. * In the spring of 2009 this led to another spectacular lawsuit: After raids in [[Lüneburg]], [[Wolfenbüttel]] and [[Braunschweig]] three men were [[Detention (imprisonment)|arrested]], who ran a tracker with 24.500 copied movies, TV shows, games, audiobooks, [[eBook]]s, music and software. This was characterized particularly by the fact that every user had to pay a fee to access the tracker. In addition, extensive [[User guide|instructions]] were provided to make the access to pirate copies simply as possible for less experienced people too.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/653.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124112337/http://www.gvu.de/media/pdf/653.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-01-24 |title=Annual Report 2009 |publisher=GVU |format=PDF |date=2010-10-21 |accessdate=2012-11-23 }} * The annual report also points to another important event: In 2005, the Swiss organization SAFE had received a notice of information about a large Payserver ring. Since the physical location was in [[Germany]], the persecution was handed over to the local association. The GVU set a criminal complaint against the head of the server in 2009. * In March 2010, the GVU presented a criminal complaint, which was directed against a [[projectionist]] from [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. The projectionist was one of the most active Cinegroups and procured high-quality pirated audio material for the production of pirated copies. The investigations of the association revealed that they were identical to the original material even to the audio [[watermark]]ing. The group ended their activities completely after the arrest of the projectionist. * Another complaint in the same year was directed against the streaming hosting clickandload on which more than 20 terabytes of pirated copies were provided. According to the GVU-investigation the platform was organized as far-flung release group and, in particular, those who provided an illegally copy, shared revenue from [[advertising]] on the [[Website|site]]. During the police investigation the portal was completely shut down. Against the relevant uploader clickandload also proceedings were initiated. In the following years, the association wants especially to tackle the financing of "piracy". The aim of the operation is to prevent professional service of ad-funded websites with pirated works.{{cite web|url=http://www.gvu.de/25_208_Alexander_Skipis_in_den_GVU_Vorstand_gewaehlt_Austrocknen_von_Finanzquellen_digitaler_Hehler_im_Jahr_2013_ein_Schwerpunktthema_der_GVU.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130206185156/http://www.gvu.de/25_208_Alexander_Skipis_in_den_GVU_Vorstand_gewaehlt_Austrocknen_von_Finanzquellen_digitaler_Hehler_im_Jahr_2013_ein_Schwerpunktthema_der_GVU.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-06 |title=In 2013, the GVU focuses on Financing of Piracy |publisher=GVU |date=2012-12-03 |accessdate=2012-12-06 |language=German }} === Platform Kino.to === [[File:KinoToScreenshot.jpg|300px|thumbnail|Message from the Criminal Police]] The most important proceeding of the GVU in the last decade was against Kino.to. In June 2011 Kino.to was one of the 50 most visited sites in Germany and was thus well known to the general public. According to the film industry over 96 per cent of visitors were located in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. At Kino.to it was possible to view tens of thousands of videos via so-called Streams, including numerous high-quality [[Movie theater|movies]] and [[Television program|TV series]].{{cite web | url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/229865/article.html | title = Police Shut Down German Movie-streaming Portal | author = Jeremy Kirk | publisher = PCWorld | date = 2011-06-09 | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} Since Kino.to has become available in March 2008, the GVU was determined to go against its backers. According to the GVU, the process was difficult, as those behind Kino.to had specifically concealed their [[Identity (social science)|identities]]. For example, the [[top-level domain]] [[.to]] was chosen, as the responsible authority in [[Tonga]] does not releases any information about the respective owners of domains. Only when the third formal complaint by the Association was reported to the authorities in Dresden on April 28, 2011, the desired outcome was achieved: In early June, in [[Police raid|raids]] across several [[Europe]]an countries, several persons were arrested who were directly involved in Kino.to - including the owner Dirk B.{{cite web | title = Police take down Kino.to in massive anti-piracy operation | url = http://www.techspot.com/news/44187-police-take-down-kinoto-in-massive-anti-piracy-operation.html | publisher = TechSpot | author = Emil Protalinski | date = 2011-06-10 | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} Mainly responsible for the success was the Integrierte Ermittlungseinheit Sachsen (INES, Integrated Detection Unit Saxony). During the course of process Kino.to was shut down on the suspicion of the backers forming a criminal organization and copyright infringement on an industrial scale. A message relating to the criminal investigation is now found at Kino.to. What is seen in the film industry as a major success fuelled huge criticisms by the majority of Kino.to users. As a direct result of the closure of Kino.to, [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] started an attack on the [[Web server]] of the GVU, which finally led to an overload and failure of the website. In addition under the name KinoX.to a portal got created which is a direct descendant of Kino.to.{{cite web | url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/german-piracy-site-kinoto-relaunches-210099 | title = German Piracy Site Kino.to Relaunches as KinoX.to | publisher = The Hollywood Reporter | author = Scott Roxborough | date = 2011-12-07 | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} The GVU has now also initiated an investigation into this portal. In addition, the association and authorities are investigating the [[Online advertising|advertising]] and marketing of Kino.to and KinoX.to.{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/video/anonymous-retaliates-against-kino-to-take-down/ |date=2011-06-09 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |title=Anonymous retaliates against Kino.to takedown |publisher=GigaOM |author=Janko Roettgers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203205442/http://gigaom.com/video/anonymous-retaliates-against-kino-to-take-down/ |archivedate=2012-02-03 |df= }} == Malware == A [[Trojan horse (computing)|Trojan]], which had been discovered for the first time on 20 March 2012, used the [[logo]] of GVU without permission of the Association. It targets and infects PCs running Microsoft [[Windows XP]] or later versions and claims to have [[Ransomware|locked the PC]] on behalf of the GVU, as pirated content had been detected on it. In fact not a single file on the hard disk is checked; however the user is prompted to pay a fee in order to regain access to the computer. Usually, the requested amount is between 50 and 100 euros and is to be paid via [[paysafecard]] or (now defunct) [[Ukash]].{{cite web | url = http://www.2-spyware.com/remove-gvu-virus.html | title = Remove GVU Virus - Removal Instructions | publisher = 2Spyware | author = Ugnius Kiguolis | accessdate = 2011-12-23}} Meanwhile, numerous variants of the GVU Trojan are circulating purporting to be a program of the [[Federal Office for Information Security|Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik]] (BSI, Federal Office for Information Security) or the [[Gesellschaft für musikalische Aufführungs- und mechanische Vervielfältigungsrechte]] (GEMA, Society for musical performing and mechanical reproduction rights). Due to the widespread use of the Trojan, in August 2012 the GVU released its first statement regarding the [[malware]], aimed in particular at the malware authors. It was speculated that the Trojan was written by operators of illegal streaming portals in order to open up new financial sources. The page KinoX.to which strongly resembles Kino.to was used for the mass dissemination of new variants of the malware according to GVU.{{cite web |url=http://www.gvu-blog.de/?p=427 |title=What Kinox has to do with the GVU Trojans? |publisher=GVU Blog |author=Christine Ehlers |date=2012-08-14 |accessdate=2011-12-23 |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817122054/http://www.gvu-blog.de/?p=427 |archivedate=2012-08-17 |df= }} == Criticism == In January 2006 the GVU was itself under investigation. The state prosecution of [[Ellwangen]] accused the association of having promoted the illegal distribution of copyrighted material. As the accusation details the association had allegedly had financial dealings with an administrator of the so-called IOH server, over which numerous release groups had collected and distributed copied content. In addition, the association got accused of directly providing hardware for the operation of the server. During the course of the investigation the business premises of the GVU in Hamburg, as well as the [[apartment|home]] of a senior employee, were searched. The GVU has officially confirmed the raid and, according to the authorities, made available all of the information. Due to the particular urgency of the case, the action gained widespread media attention. However, suspicions against the association have not been confirmed. The investigation has since halted.{{cite web | url = http://www.onlinekosten.de/news/artikel/19848/0/Razzia-Ermittlungen-gegen-die-GVU | title = Roundup: Investigation of the GVU | language = German | publisher = Onlinekosten | author = Volker Briegleb | date = 2006-01-24 | accessdate = 2012-11-23}} Also, during another investigation, the role of the GVU was criticised: The [[Kiel]] District Court said that during the course of proceedings against a suspected software pirates, it is essential to ensure the independence of police investigative work. Specifically, there were complaints that an employee of the GVU had worked as an expert in the process and at the same time had a free hand in the analysis of seized computers. The requirement of impartiality, not only for [[judge]]s but also for prosecutors and the [[police]] had, in their opinion, not been fully safeguarded. Investigating authorities were prohibited to privatize their work.{{cite web |url=http://www.schleswig-holstein.de/LGKIEL/EN/LGKIEL_node.html |title=Official Website of the Kiel District Court |publisher=Schleswig-Holstein |accessdate=2012-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201081913/http://www.schleswig-holstein.de/LGKIEL/EN/LGKIEL_node.html |archivedate=2012-12-01 |df= }} Also, the strategy of the GVU in luring software pirates through a so-called [[Honeypot (computing)|honey pot]] trap has remained a subject of criticism. For example, during the course a raid in autumn 2007 suspicions were raised that the GVU and other organizations had installed open [[File Transfer Protocol|FTP servers]] on network, intended for the use by release groups, thus enabling the determination release group members based on their [[IP address]]. According to the unanimous opinion of experts, this approach is, at least legally, unobjectionable. Individual media outlets have criticised the GVU’s close proximity to [[lawyer]]s, prosecutors, police and internet [[service provider]]s, although naturally these kind of co-operations are part of the work of any interest group. The Association’s close cooperation with various other organizations is repeatedly criticized, especially during its annual Industry Forum. In August 2010, the GVU was suspected of having caused the unjustified removal of several posts on the video platform [[Vimeo]], which had been published under a [[Creative Commons]] license and are therefore available to all. Among other contents, "You are a terrorist" and "Electric Reporter" were affected. During the course of the investigation into the case it was revealed that the removal of the content was not initiated by the association, but by the company OpSec Security, based in [[Munich]]. The authors Alexander Lehmann and Mario Sixtus were able to obtain an injunction against the company and the GVU has since explicitly distanced itself from the company. According to the GVU, OpSec Security had at no point been contracted to clear videos from Vimeo in its name.{{cite web | url = http://torrentfreak.com/anti-piracy-failure-takes-down-creative-commons-video-100812/ | title = Anti-Piracy Failure Takes Down Creative Commons Videos | publisher = TorrentFreak | date = 2010-08-12 | accessdate = 2011-11-23}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.dach-contentprotection.org/index.php?id=57&L=1 DACH Content Protection] (Englisch / German) * [http://www.gvu.de/ Corporate Website of the GVU] (in German) * [http://www.gvu-blog.de/ Official Blog of the GVU] (in German) {{Coord|52|31|26.34|N|13|19|41.2|E|display=title}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gvu}} [[Category:Arts and media trade groups]] [[Category:Communications and media organisations based in Germany]] [[Category:Copyright law organizations]] [[Category:Entertainment organizations]] [[Category:1984 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1984]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Berlin]]

{{Italic title}} '''''In Mourning and in Rage''''' was a work of [[performance art]] and activism by [[Suzanne Lacy]] and [[Leslie Labowitz-Starus|Leslie Labowitz]]. The performance took place in [[Los Angeles]], California in 1977 as a response to the rapes and murders covered by the media in the "[[Hillside Strangler]]" case.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Labowitz-Starus|first=Leslie|last2=Lacy|first2=Suzanne|date=1978-01-01|title="In Mourning and in Rage ..."|jstor=3345993|journal=Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies|volume=3|issue=1|pages=52–55|doi=10.2307/3345993}}</ref>"As if the horror of these crimes wasn't enough, the press coverage of the events sensationalized the sexual nature of the crimes. For feminist activists in Los Angeles involved in the movement to end violence against women, this analysis was unacceptable."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moravec|first1=Michelle|title=In Mourning and In Rage|url=http://historyinthecity.blogspot.com/2011/09/in-mourning-and-in-rage.html|website=History of the City|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref>
A continuation of ''Three Weeks in May,'' Lacy and Labowitz designed ''In Mourning and in Rage'' as a personal response to the sensationalized media coverage of violence against women as well as an expression of grief and rage towards the loss of life. The performance was a collaboration between Lacy, Labowitz, Bia Lowe, [[Holly Near]], City Councilwoman Pat Russel, the [[Woman's Building]], Women Against Violence Against Women, and Los Angeles Commission on Assaults Against Women. The event was staged for mass media coverage at the [[Los Angeles City Hall]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.suzannelacy.com/in-mourning-and-in-rage-1977/|title=In Mourning and In Rage (1977)|website=SUZANNE LACY|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/women-art-and-society/oclc/930389708&referer=brief_results|title=Women, art, and society|last=Chadwick|first=Whitney|date=2012-01-01|publisher=Thames & Hudson|isbn=9780500204054|location=London|language=English}}</ref>
The performance consisted of a large funeral motorcade of black-clad women lead by a hearse from the [[Woman's Building]] to the Los Angeles City Hall. Once there, nine seven-feet-tall women draped in black emerged from the hearse along with a women dressed in red. The mourners then climbed the steps of city hall where each of the nine women gave a statement into a microphone expressing their solidarity with the murdered women, emphasized by a chorus of "In memory of our sisters, we fight back!" from the rest of the motorcade.<ref name=":0" /> By making this performance public as well as highly crafted for media coverage, Lacy and Labowitz looked to highlight not only the deaths of the ten women killed by the [[Hillside Strangler]], but the significantly larger population of women victims whose stories went uncovered by mainstream media.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/801307168|title=Pacific standard time : Los Angeles art 1945-1980|last=Rebecca.|first=Peabody,|last2=Calif.)|first2=J. Paul Getty Museum (Los Angeles,|date=2011-01-01|publisher=The Getty Research Institute and the J. Paul Getty Museum|year=|isbn=1606060724|location=|pages=258–259|oclc=801307168}}</ref>
The piece concluded with direct statements to the press explaining the rationale for the piece as well as a speech demanding resources for women's self defense. Singer-songwriter [[Holly Near]] performed her song "Fight Back"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Near|first1=Holly|title=Fight Back|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sBE4Au5myko|website=Youtube|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> which was written specifically for this event.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Irish|first1=Sharon|title=Suzanne Lacy: Spaces Between|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s0fCKMCOdO0C&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=fight+back+holly+near+composed+lacy&source=bl&ots=Q4DGhJL3eI&sig=kM9wgfqVxJWggucbF-__So5cXqo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiHro--i_zSAhXmsFQKHdNmDVsQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=fight%20back%20holly%20near%20composed%20lacy&f=false|website=Google Books|publisher=Univ Of Minnesota Press (February 12, 2010)|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
== Legacy == ''In Mourning and in Rage'' was highly covered by the press and resulted in increased support from Los Angeles City Council members and a pledge from the Rape Hotline Alliance to provide self defense classes.<ref name=":1" />
To further the conversation about social action and art, Lacy and Labowitz produced a video documenting ''In Mourning and in Rage'' as well as a pamphlet entitled ''What is Social Art?.''
== See also == * ''[[Three Weeks in May]]'' * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idK02tPdYV0&t=21s In Mourning and In Rage Video Documentation]
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Performance art in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Performances]]

{{For|other mosques with similar names|Jameh Mosque}} {{Infobox religious building |image= Jameh Mosque of Amol.JPG |caption= |building_name= Jāmeh Mosque of [[Amol]] |location= {{flagicon|Iran}} [[Amol]], Iran |map_type = Iran | map_relief = 1 |coordinates = {{coord|38.0810|N|46.2904|E|source:wikidata|display=title,inline}} |religious_affiliation= [[Shia Islam]] |province= [[Mazandaran Province]] |municipality= [[Amol County]] |website= |architect= |architecture_type= Mosque |architecture_style= |specifications= |year_completed=[[Safavid dynasty]]
[[Qajar dynasty]] |construction_cost= |capacity= |dome_quantity= |dome_height_outer= |dome_dia_outer= |minaret_quantity= |minaret_height= }} The '''Jāmeh Mosque of Amol''' ({{lang-fa|مسجد جامع آمل}} – ''Masjid-e-Jāmeh Amol'')[http://www.arthut.co/mosque/item/517-amol-jame-mosque ArtHut, Jameh Mosque of Amol] is the grand, congregational mosque (Jāmeh) of [[Amol]], [[Mazandaran Province]], Iran.[http://www.masjed.ir/en/article/1815/Jam-e-Mosque-of-Amol Masjed portal, Jame Mosque of Amol][http://english.irib.ir/radioculture/iran/tourism/item/146474-amol-attractions-historical-natural Amol attractions, English.irib][http://www..org/Results.aspx?PageIndex=1&SearchEverything=Populated+Places+in+Amol+County Worldjournals, Mosque of Mazandaran]Mosque location in Amol Sassanid Bazaar. Its primary structure dates to the first century AH and during the reign of the [[Qajar dynasty]] and [[Safavid dynasty]] renovation.[http://www.itto.org/tourismattractions/?sight=279 Jame Mosque of Amol, Itto.org] ==See also== * [[List of Mosques in Iran]] {{commonscat-inline|Masjed-e Jameh, Amol}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Mosques in Iran}} {{Mazandaran Province}} [[Category:Mosques in Iran]] [[Category:Iranian architecture]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Amol]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Mazandaran Province]] [[Category:11th-century mosques]] {{Iran-mosque-stub}}

page.title: List of books featured on Book of the Week in 2014

revision.comment: add {{[[Template:Book of the Week|Book of the Week]]}}
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of books featured on ''Book of the Week'' in 2014}} {{for|other years|List of books featured on Book of the Week}} This is a list of books which have been featured on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Book of the Week]]'' during 2014.
==2014==
===January<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 06-10 – ''[[The Telling Room]]'' by [[Michael Paterniti]], read by [[Will Adamsdale]]. * 13–17 – ''[[Priscilla: The Hidden Life of an Englishwoman in Wartime France]]'' by [[Nicholas Shakespeare]], read by author. * 20–24 – ''[[Gold: The Race for the World's Most Seductive Metal]]'' by [[Matthew Hart (author)]], read by author. * 27–31 – ''[[White Beech: The Rainforest Years]]'' by [[Germaine Greer]], read by author.
===February<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 03-07 – ''[[Where Memories Go: Why Dementia Changes Everything]]'' by [[Sally Magnusson]], read by author. * 10–14 – ''[[The Almost Nearly Perfect People: The Truth About the Nordic Miracle]]'' by [[Michael Booth]], read by [[Gunnar Cauthery]]. * 17–21 – ''[[The Last Asylum]]'' by [[Barbara Taylor]], read by [[Maggie Steed]]. * 24–28 – ''[[Twelve Years a Slave]]'' by [[Solomon Northup]], read by [[Rhashan Stone]].
===March<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 03-07 – ''[[The Fun Stuff]]'' by [[James Wood (critic)|James Wood]], read by [[Peter Firth]]. * 10–14 – ''A Sense of Direction'' by [[Gideon Lewis-Kraus]], read by [[Patrick Kennedy (actor)|Patrick Kennedy]]. * 17–21 – ''[[Free at Last - The Benn Diaries 1991 to 2001]]'' by [[Tony Benn]], read by author. * 24–28 – ''[[A Spy Among Friends]]'' by [[Ben Macintyre]], read by [[Simon Russell Beale]]. * 31-04 – ''[[The Unexpected Professor]]'' by [[John Carey (critic)|John Carey]], read by [[Nicholas Farrell]].
===April<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 07-11 – ''[[Louis Armstrong: Master of Modernism]]'' by [[Thomas Brothers]], read by [[Colin McFarlane]]. * 14–18 – ''[[B is for Bauhaus: An A-Z of the Modern World]]'' by [[Deyan Sudjic]], read by author. * 21–24 – ''[[The Land Where Lemons Grow]]'' by [[Helena Attlee]], read by [[Francesca Dymond]]. * 28-02 – ''The Valley'' by [[Richard Benson (author)|Richard Benson]], read by Richard Stacey.
===May<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 05-09 – ''[[Eleanor Marx: A Life]]'' by [[Rachel Holmes]], read by [[Tracy-Ann Oberman]]. * 12–16 – ''[[Gironimo! Riding the Very Terrible 1914 Tour of Italy]]'' by [[Tim Moore (writer)|Tim Moore]], read by [[Stephen Mangan]]. * 19–23 – ''[[Stringer: A Reporter's Journey in the Congo]]'' by [[Anjan Sundaram]], read by [[Riz Ahmed]]. * 26–30 – ''[[Doubling Back]]'' by [[Linda Cracknell]], read by [[Teresa Gallagher]].
===June<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 02-06 – ''[[A Broken Hallelujah: Leonard Cohen's Secret Chord]]'' by [[Liel Leibovitz]], read by [[Julian Barrett]] and [[Colin Stinton]]. * 09-13 – ''[[Curious: True Stories and Loose Connections]]'' by [[Rebecca Front]], read by author. * 16–20 – ''[[As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning]]'' by [[Laurie Lee]], read by [[Tobias Menzies]]. * 30-04 – ''[[Last Days of the Bus Club]]'' by [[Chris Stewart (author)|Chris Stewart]], read by the author.
===July<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 07-11 – ''[[The Zhivago Affair]]'' by Peter Finn and [[Petra Couvee]], read by [[Nigel Anthony]]. * 14–18 – ''[[Last Man Off]]'' by [[Matt Lewis (marine biologist)]], read by [[Sam Troughton]]. * 21–25 – ''[[Deep (book)]]'' by [[James Nestor (writer)|James Nestor]], read by the author. * 28-01 – ''[[Cold Blood (book)]]'' by [[Richard Kerridge]], read by [[Robert Powell]].
===August<ref name=BBC_epguide />=== * 04-08 – ''[[In Montmartre]]'' by [[Sue Roe]], read by [[Stella Gonet]]. * 11–15 – ''[[Mona Lisa: A Life Discovered]]'' by [[Dianne Hales]], read by [[Nancy Crane]]. * 18–22 – ''[[On Silbury Hill]]'' by [[Adam Thorpe]], read by the author. * 25–29 – ''[[Philip Larkin: Life, Art and Love]]'' by [[James Booth]], read by [[Michael Pennington]].
===September<ref name=BBC_epguide>{{cite web|title=Book of the Week: Episode Guide|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006qftk/episodes/guide#b04jh4cx|website=BBC Radio|publisher=BBC|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref>=== * 01-05 – ''[[Hopeful: The Autobiography]]'' by [[Omid Djalili]], read by the author. * 08-12 – ''[[Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind]]'' by [[Yuval Harari|Yuval Noah Harari]], read by [[Adrian Scarborough]]. * 15–19 – ''[[Please, Mr Postman (book)]]'' by [[Alan Johnson]], read by the author. * 22–26 – ''[[Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh]]'' by [[John Lahr]], read by [[Damian Lewis]].
===October=== There are no books listed for October.
===November=== * 10–15 ''Forensics: The Anatomy of Crime'' – [[Val McDermid]] * 17–21 ''Not My Father's Son: A Family Memoir'' – [[Alan Cumming]] * 24–29 ''My Life in Houses'' – [[Margaret Forster]]
===December=== * 01-05 ''Discontent and Its Civilisations'' – [[Mohsin Hamid]] * 08-12 ''Elsa Schiaparelli: A Biography'' – [[Meryle Secrest]] * 15–20 * 22–27 ''Stories in the Stars'' – [[Susanna Hislop]] * ''Schubert's Winter Journey'' – Ian Bostridge
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Book of the Week}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Book of the Week in 2014, List of books featured on}} [[Category:Lists of books]] [[Category:Lists of radio series episodes]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Louisville Gardens | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[File:Louisville Gardens roadwork.jpg|250px]] | caption = | fullname = | former names = Jefferson County Armory, Louisville Convention Center | location = [[Louisville, Kentucky]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1905 <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Louisville, Kentucky|City of Louisville]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | publictransit = {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name =Jefferson County Armory | nrhp_type = | coordinates = {{coord|38|15|5.06|N|85|45|37.26|W|display=inline,title}} | area = | built =1905 | architect= [[Brinton B. Davis|Davis, Brinton B.]] | builder=[[Caldwell & Drake]] | architecture= [[Beaux Arts architecture|Beaux Arts]] | added = March 24, 1980 | governing_body = Local | refnum=80001606 <ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> }} }} '''Louisville Gardens''' is a multi-purpose, 6,000-seat [[arena]], in [[Louisville, Kentucky]], that opened in 1905, as the '''Jefferson County Armory'''. It celebrated its 100th anniversary as former city mayor [[Jerry Abramson]]'s official "Family-Friendly New Years Eve" celebration location. It was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980.
==History== The facility has served the city of Louisville and [[Jefferson County, Kentucky|Jefferson County]] in a variety of ways during the past century, from utilization as an actual armory to [[American Basketball Association]]'s [[Kentucky Colonels]] basketball games, to various wrestling events, concerts, political rallies, and [[Hurricane Katrina]] flood relief have also been staged there. More recently, [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] used the 3,000-person capacity arena as a training ground for future stars in a minor-league [[professional wrestling promotion|promotion]] known as [[Ohio Valley Wrestling]], until the organization moved to the [[Davis Arena]]. WWE also staged two [[pay-per-view]] events while the venue was known as '''Louisville Gardens''': ([[In Your House 6]] and [[Ground Zero: In Your House|In Your House 17: Ground Zero]]). TNA Wrestling held an event at the venue in 2007. [[Freedom Hall]] replaced the small, aging facility in 1956, as a more popular venue for city events. [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] (Tuesday, August 23, 1960)<ref>http://www.thekingcenter.org/archive/document/mlk-jefferson-county-armory</ref> and [[Harry Truman]] both spoke at the arena.
==Use as basketball arena== Primary home of [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball]] starting in 1945 when [[Bernard Hickman|Bernard "Peck" Hickman]] was head coach until the 1957–58 season when they moved to Freedom Hall. They played a few more games there up until their last on November 30, 1972. The Louisville Cardinals were 153-23 all time at the armory.<ref>http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20101010/SPORTS0203/310100032/Louisville-basketball-has-had-many-homes-before-KFC-Yum-Center</ref> The [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky Wildcats]] when led by [[Adolph Rupp]] played 72 games at the armory going 61-11 there from 1937 to 1956<ref>http://www.bigbluehistory.net/bb/statistics/arenajeffersoncountyarmory.html</ref> Included in that was games played in the [[SEC Men's Basketball Tournament]] which was held at the armory from 1941 to 1952. Additionally, the [[Ohio Valley Conference]] men's basketball tournament was held there from 1949 to 1955 and again from 1964 to 1967.
The [[Kentucky Colonels]], of the [[American Basketball Association]], played their home games at the facility, then known as the '''Louisville Convention Center''', from 1967 through 1970. [[Louie Dampier]] was the team's best player in the era.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.remembertheaba.com/Kentucky-Colonels.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522142515/http://www.remembertheaba.com/Kentucky-Colonels.html |archivedate=2015-05-22 |df= }}</ref> On November 24, 1968, [[Penny Ann Earley]] became the first female to appear in a men's professional league, playing briefly in a home game for the Colonels.<ref>http://www.remembertheaba.com/OnlyintheABAMaterial/OnlyInTheABA/PAEarly/PAEarly.html</ref>
The [[Louisville Catbirds]], of the [[Continental Basketball Association]] (1983–1985), the [[Louisville Shooters]], of the [[Global Basketball Association]] (1991–1992) and the [[Kentucky Colonels (ABA 2000)|Kentucky Colonels]], of the [[ABA 2000]] (2004–2006), all played their home basketball games at the Louisville Gardens. The [[Louisville Cardinals|University of Louisville]] women's basketball team used the Gardens for six home games in the 1997–98 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guide.provations.com/louisville/womensbb2010#pg161 |title=Records: Home/Attendance |work=2010–11 Louisville Cardinals Women's Basketball Media Guide |publisher=University of Louisville Sports information |format=PDF |page=159 |accessdate=March 5, 2011}}</ref> [[Ice hockey]] teams to use the Gardens as home ice include the [[Louisville Blades]], [[Louisville Shooting Stars]] and the [[Louisville Rebels]].
==Other names== The building was also known as the Convention Center or Louisville Convention Center, mostly in the 1960s and 1970s. It was renamed Louisville Gardens in 1975 when the Commonwealth Convention Center (now called [[Kentucky International Convention Center]]) was being built.
==Current status== In 2007, the [[Cordish Company]], manager of the nearby [[Fourth Street Live!]] entertainment complex, agreed to take over operation of "The Gardens" from the [[Louisville Metro Council|Metro Louisville Government]] as part of a $250 million development in [[downtown Louisville]]. In 2012, Cordish was released from its obligations to the Gardens.<ref>[http://www.wdrb.com/story/19568501/cordish-obligation-to-revamp-louisville-gardens-optional Cordish obligation to revamp Louisville Gardens 'optional']</ref>
==See also== * [[Sports in Louisville, Kentucky]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * {{cite news |publisher=''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' |date=2000-05-07 |title=Gardens may need niche to survive |last=Shafer |first=Sheldon}} * {{cite news |publisher=''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' |date=2007-08-30 |title=Historic Gardens may flourish again |last=Shafer |first=Sheldon}}

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "group of standing stones in Alcoutim, Portugal" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|group of standing stones in Alcoutim, Portugal}} {{Infobox ancient site | name = Menhirs of Lavajo | native_name = | alternate_name = <!-- image & map --> | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_type = | map_caption = Location of the dolmen in the municipality of Alcoutim | map_size = 235 | coordinates = {{coord|37|30|5|N|7|32|6|W|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Faro (district)|Faro]], [[Algarve]], [[Algarve]], [[Portugal]] | type = [[Menhir]] | part_of = <!-- stats --> | altitude_m = | length = | width = | area = | volume = | diameter = | circumference = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = <!-- actually displays as 'Periods' --> | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | discovered = | excavations = | archaeologists = unknown | condition = | ownership = Portuguese Republic | management = | public_access = Private IC27 {{convert|1200|km|mi}} north of the village of Afonso Vicente. Located near the municipal frontier and the border with Spain (delimited by the [[Guadiana]] | website = | notes = <!-- Other --> | other_designation = }} The '''Menhirs of Lavajo''' ({{lang-pt|Menires de Lavajo}}) are a group of [[menhir]]s, located in the [[Freguesia (Portugal)|civil parish]] of [[Alcoutim e Pereiro]] in the [[Concelho|municipality]] of [[Alcoutim]], [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[Algarve]].
==History== [[File:MenirLavajoI.JPG|170px|left|thumb|The largest menhir of the megalithic group]]
These structures are territorial marks or define sacred spaces from the [[Late Neolithic]] or [[Chalcolithic]] period (constructed sometime between 3500 and 2800 B.C.).<ref name="SIPA">{{cite web |url=http://www.monumentos.pt/Site/APP_PagesUser/SIPA.aspx?id=32266 |title=Menires de Lavajo/Conjunto megalítico de Lavajo (IPA.00032266/PT050802010019) |publisher=SIPA–Sistema de Informação para o Património Arquitectónico |editor=SIPA |location=Lisbon, Portugal |language=Portuguese |first=Rosário |last=Gordalina |year=2011 |accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>
The first excavations in 1998, revealed the existence of not only the large menhir, but fragments of the two small menhirs.<ref name=SIPA/> These menhirs raised the possibility that the group was an intentional alignment of these structures.<ref name=SIPA/> One of these structures were eventually stored in the archaeological museum in Alcoutim.<ref name=SIPA/>
==Architecture== A rural group, located on a small {{convert|155|m|ft}} hilltop, between the Lavajo valley and the ravine of the same name. The area is encircled by fence.<ref name=SIPA/>
Part of an aligned group of megalithic religious structures. Consists of three carved menhirs, with the largest decorated with carvings and circles. The largest (Lavajo I) is {{convert|3.14|m|ft}} high, dark grey phallic-form structure, with its surface stained in brown.<ref name=SIPA/> Its carvings combine decoration arranged along a longitudinal groove, with circles and other elements.<ref name=SIPA/> The other two menhirs (Lavajo II) located {{convert|250|m|ft}}, decorated in a similar fashion, with one decorated by perforated circle.<ref name=SIPA/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cms.cm-alcoutim.pt.vf-host.com/upload_files/client_id_1/website_id_1/Concelho/Turismo/o_que_visitar_/Menir%20Lavajo/Folheto%20menir.pdf |editor=Câmara Municipal |publisher=Câmara Municipal de Alcoutim |title=Menhires of Lavajo |accessdate=5 April 2015 |language=Portuguese}}</ref>
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|30em}} ;Sources * {{citation |last=Cardoso |first=João Luís |contribution=Menires do Alto Algarve Oriental: Lavajo I e Lavajo II (Alcoutim) |title=Revista Portuguesa de Arqueologia |volume=5 |issue=2 |year=2002 |language=Portuguese |pages=99-133}} * {{citation |last=Gomes |first=M.V. |last2=Cardoso |first2=J.L. |last3=Joaquim |first3=A.N. |contribution=Testemunhos megalíticos de Afonso Vicente (Alcoutim): Notícia preliminar |title=Revista Almadan |location=Almada, Portugal |volume=Série II |issue=1 |year=1992 |pages=92-133 |language=Portuguese}}

page.title: National Committee for the History of Art

revision.text:
The '''National Committee for the History of Art''' (NCHA) is the U.S. affiliate of the [[Comité International d'Histoire de l'Art]] (CIHA, i.e. the international community of art historians). It was founded in 1980 by [[Irving Lavin]].
Both committees aim to foster intellectual exchange among scholars and students interested in all fields of art history. They organize scholarly conferences and promote the communication, dissemination and exchange of knowledge and information about art history in order to promote a global community of art historians.
The NCHA is supported by the [[Getty Foundation]] and interested in developing global networks of art historians, particularly in areas of the world in which art history is an emerging discipline. Therefore, it brings together art historians from Africa, Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and Eastern Europe for discussions on the state of the discipline. The NCHA also provides travel support to congresses for students enrolled in US doctoral programs.
The current president of the NCHA is [[Marc Gotlieb]], Director of the Graduate Program and Class of 1955 Memorial Professor of Art at [[Williams College]], [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]].
==External links== *{{official website|http://wp.nchart.org/}}
