revision.comment: text & ref on Noseda contract extension
revision.text:
{{for|the National Symphony Orchestras of other countries|National Symphony Orchestra (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox orchestra | name = National Symphony Orchestra | short_name = NSO | image = Banner_of_the_NSO.jpg | caption = Kennedy Center | background = classical_ensemble | founded = {{Start date|1931}} | location = [[Washington DC]], [[United States]] | concert_hall = [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]] | website = {{URL|www.kennedy-center.org/nso}} | music_director = [[Gianandrea Noseda]] }} The '''National Symphony Orchestra''' ('''NSO'''), founded in 1931, is an American [[Orchestra|symphony orchestra]] based in [[Washington, D.C.]]. Its principal performing venue is the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts]].
==History== For the first period of its history, the NSO performed in [[Constitution Hall]]. During the tenure of the first music director, [[Hans Kindler]], the musicians received a salary of $40.00 per week, for three rehearsals and one concert, for five months of the year.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/02/AR2005090200542_pf.html | title=The NSO: 75 and Counting Its Blessings | work=Washington Post | author=Tim Page |date=2005-09-04 | accessdate=2007-03-18}}</ref> The first female member of the NSO was a harpist, [[Sylvia Meyer]], who joined in 1933.<ref name=wapo>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|date=March 30, 2005|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/03/29/AR2005032901247.html|title=Esteemed NSO Harpist Sylvia Meyer}}</ref>
Kindler and the NSO made several 78-rpm recordings for [[RCA Victor]], including the two Roumanian Rhapsodies by [[George Enescu]]; much later, in 1960, the NSO would perform the first of these works under the baton of the visiting Romanian conductor [[George Georgescu]], a close associate and favored exponent of the composer.<ref name=Programme>Programme for National Symphony Orchestra performances of December 13–15, 1960.</ref> One of the more unusual RCA recordings with the orchestra was of the complete ballet music from the opera ''King Henry VIII'' by [[Camille Saint-Saëns]], one of the very few recordings conducted by [[Walter Damrosch]]. Years later, [[Howard Mitchell]] made a series of [[stereophonic]] recordings with the orchestra for RCA. [[Antal Doráti]] recorded with the orchestra for [[Decca Records]]. [[Mstislav Rostropovich]] made recordings for [[Telefunken|Teldec]], [[Sony Records]], and [[Erato Records|Erato]]. The orchestra returned to RCA Victor under [[Leonard Slatkin]], until RCA abandoned new [[classical music|classical]] recordings.
In 1986, the NSO became the artistic affiliate of the [[Kennedy Center]], where it has presented a concert season annually since the Center opened in 1971.
==Activities== The NSO regularly participates in events of national and international importance, including performances for ceremonial state affairs, presidential inaugurations and official holiday celebrations, including concerts for [[Memorial Day]] and the regular ''[[A Capitol Fourth]]'' concerts on 4 July.
The NSO itself numbers 100 musicians, presenting a 52-week season of approximately 175 concerts each year. These include classical subscription series, [[Traditional pop music|pops]] concerts, and educational programs. In addition to these activities, small groups of NSO members develop education programs designed at age levels from pre-kindergarten through high school. Collectively, these ensembles present as many as 100 additional performances a year during the [[#AR|American Residencies]] and at the Kennedy Center.
Through the John and June Hechinger Commissioning Fund for New Orchestral Works, the NSO has commissioned more than 50 works, including cycles of fanfares and encores. During his tenure, Slatkin founded the National Conducting Institute in 2000.
Also of note is the National Symphony Orchestra Summer Music Institute. For more than a decade, [[scholarships]] provided by the National Trustees of the National Symphony Orchestra have enabled top-level students from across the country and from many nations to come to the nation’s capital for several weeks of study with NSO musicians. These participants, selected from a competitive pool of applicants, come from a variety of backgrounds, some currently enrolled in music conservatories such as [[Juilliard]] and others still completing high school.
[[Image:Nancy Reagan directs the National Symphony.jpg|thumb|right|First Lady [[Nancy Reagan]] conducts the National Symphony Orchestra, 1987]] {{Anchor|AR}}Another important project is the National Symphony Orchestra American Residencies for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. This venture encompasses sharing all elements of classical symphonic music with a specific region of the United States, exploring the diversity of musical influences, and giving the region a musical voice in the nation’s center for the performing arts through exchanges, training programs, and commissions. Established in 1992, the project has taken the NSO to fifteen states.
In November 2004, the orchestra announced the conclusion of Slatkin's NSO directorship in 2008. One report spoke of tensions between the conductor and the orchestra, and mentioned criticisms of Slatkin's programming and rehearsal styles.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A57371-2004Nov17.html?sub=AR |title=Slatkin, NSO to Part in 2008 | work=Washington Post | author=Tim Page | date=2004-11-18 | accessdate=2007-03-18}}</ref> With the 2006–2007 season, [[Iván Fischer]] became the principal guest conductor of the orchestra.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.playbillarts.com/features/article/5442.html | title=Q&A: Iván Fischer | work=Playbill Arts | author= |date=2006-10-19 | accessdate=2007-03-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/11/AR2007021101509.html | title=Ivan Fischer: Plays Well With Children | work=Washington Post | author=Tim Page | date=2007-02-12 |accessdate=2007-03-18}}</ref> On 13 April 2007, the orchestra announced the appointment of Fischer as the orchestra's principal conductor as of the 2008–2009 season, for two seasons.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/12/AR2007041201612.html?hpid=moreheadlines | title=NSO Picks Fischer as Interim Maestro | work=Washington Post | author=Tim Page | date=2007-04-12 | accessdate=2007-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.playbillarts.com/news/article/6310.html | title=Iván Fischer Appointed Principal Conductor of DC's National Symphony Orchestra | work=Playbill Arts | date=2007-04-12 | accessdate=2007-04-14}}</ref>
On September 25, 2008, the orchestra announced the appointment of [[Christoph Eschenbach]] as the orchestra's sixth music director, effective with the 2010–2011 season, for an initial contract of four years.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/25/AR2008092504161.html?hpid=topnews | title=Christoph Eschenbach to Lead National Symphony | work=Washington Post| author=Anne Midgette | date=2008-09-25 | accessdate=2008-09-25}}</ref> In September 2011, the orchestra extended Eschenbach's contract through the 2014–2015 season, and in March 2014, his contract was extended through the 2016–2017 season.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/kennedy-center-extends-eschenbachs-contract-new-organ-in-works/2011/09/25/gIQAswnQxK_story.html | title=Kennedy Center extends Eschenbach's contract; new organ in works | work=Washington Post | author=Anne Midgette | date=2011-09-25 | accessdate=2011-09-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://web.kennedy-center.org/~/media/Files/KC/Press%20Releases/press%20release%20NSO%20and%20Kennedy%20Center%20Extend%20Christoph%20Eschenbachs%20contract%20through%20August%202017.pdf | title=Christoph Eschenbach Extends Contract as Music Director of the National Symphony Orchestra and Kennedy Center Through the 2016-2017 Season | work=Kennedy Center Press Release | date=2014-03-24 | accessdate=2014-04-06}}</ref> In February 2015, the NSO announced the scheduled conclusion of Eschenbach's tenure as NSO music director at the end of the 2016-2017 season, at which time he is scheduled to become the NSO's conductor laureate.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/style/wp/2015/02/18/eschenbachs-nso-contract-to-end-in-2017-will-become-conductor-laureate/ | title=Eschenbach’s NSO contract to end in 2017; will become conductor laureate | work=Washington Post | author=Anne Midgette | date=2015-02-18 | accessdate=2015-02-20}}</ref>
In 2011, [[Gianandrea Noseda]] first guest-conducted the NSO, and returned in November 2015 for an additional guest engagement. In January 2016, the NSO announced the appointment Noseda as its next music director, effective with the 2017–2018 season.<ref>{{cite news | author=Anne Midgette | title=National Symphony Orchestra names rising star Gianandrea Noseda as music director | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/national-symphony-orchestra-names-rising-star-gianandrea-noseda-as-music-director/2016/01/04/e3f055c8-b2b9-11e5-a842-0feb51d1d124_story.html | work=The Washington Post | date=2016-01-04 | accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref> He is to serve as music director-designate in the 2016-2017 season, and his initial contract as music director is for 4 seasons.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://web.kennedy-center.org/~/media/Files/KC/Press%20Releases/January%202016%20Releases/GIANANDREANOSEDANAMEDNATIONALSYMPHONYORCHESTRAMUSICDIRECTOR?_ga=1.156840187.1975559029.1452359132 | title=Gianandrea Noseda Named Music Director of the National Symphony Orchestra | work=Kennedy Center Press Release | date=2016-01-04 | accessdate=2016-01-09 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127025035/http://web.kennedy-center.org/~/media/Files/KC/Press%20Releases/January%202016%20Releases/GIANANDREANOSEDANAMEDNATIONALSYMPHONYORCHESTRAMUSICDIRECTOR?_ga=1.156840187.1975559029.1452359132 | archivedate=2016-01-27 | df= }}</ref> In September 2018, the NSO announced the extension of Noseda's contract through the 2024-2025 season.<ref>{{cite news | author=Anne Midgette | title=Noseda extends NSO contract; will stay through 2024-2025 season | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/noseda-extends-nso-contract-will-stay-through-2024-2025-season/2018/09/22/3c6f0a5e-bddf-11e8-be70-52bd11fe18af_story.html | work=The Washington Post | date=2018-09-23 | accessdate=2018-09-24}}</ref>
==Music directors== * [[Hans Kindler]] (1931–1949) * [[Howard Mitchell]] (1949–1970) * [[Antal Doráti]] (1970–1977) * [[Mstislav Rostropovich]] (1977–1994) * [[Leonard Slatkin]] (1996–2008) * [[Iván Fischer]] (principal conductor; 2008–2010) * [[Christoph Eschenbach]] (2010–2017) * [[Gianandrea Noseda]] (2017-present)
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *National Symphony Orchestra [http://www.kennedy-center.org/nso/ Official site] *National Symphony Orchestra [https://web.archive.org/web/20060615181920/http://www.kennedy-center.org/nso/history/75th/ History ] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/02/AR2005090200542.html National Symphony Orchestra Profile] at the [[Washington Post]]
{{NSO music directors}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Symphony Orchestra}} [[Category:American orchestras]] [[Category:Musical groups from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Members of the Cultural Alliance of Greater Washington]] [[Category:Articles needing audio and or video]] [[Category:Symphony orchestra articles needing audio and or video]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1931]] [[Category:1931 establishments in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:National orchestras|United States]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1931]] [[Category:Performing arts in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.comment: Per this: https://facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1980545642206196&id=1716619021932194 ; Also in the video, several of the pieces have been authenticated by the C14, with one still pending results. But that is probably better to add when a peer reviewed paper is published.
revision.text:
The '''Nazario Collection''' ({{lang-es|Colección Nazario}}),<ref name="PLP"/> also known as '''Agüeybaná's Library''' ({{lang-es|Biblioteca de Agüeybaná|links=no}}),<ref name="EVT"/> '''Father Nazario's Rocks''' ({{lang-es|Piedras del Padre Nazario|links=no}}),<ref name="EVT"/> and the '''Phoenician Rocks''' ({{lang-es|Piedras Fenicias|links=no}}), is the name commonly used to describe a cache of carved stones that originated at [[Guayanilla, Puerto Rico]]. According to contemporary accounts, the statuettes made of local serpentine rocks were first discovered by Catholic priest José María Nazario y Cancel during the 19th century, and feature unidentified [[petroglyphs]] that have been speculated to be connected to the [[Old World]] for over 130 years.<ref name="PLP"/> Their original site was not far from Yauco and was underground, where it was hidden under a slate that concealed a tunnel.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Overwhelmed with the quantity and difficulty of transporting a trove that totaled more than a ton, he opted to abandon his individual approach and recruited locals to aid in the moving of the rocks to his house, where he conducted the first research on them by comparing them to similar objects from other countries.<ref name="Coll"/> Nazario would combine his research with his religious background, leading to the hypothesis that there might be some connection between them and the [[Ten Lost Tribes]].
Due to the ramifications that their authentication would have on mainstream concepts of Pan-American history, the authenticity of the pieces has been in question from the onset, with researchers providing conflicting opinions.<ref name="PLP"/> Despite this, several foreign archeologists traveled to Puerto Rico in order to study the pieces.<ref name="PLP"/><ref name="ENDI">{{cite web|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/noticias/locales/nota/piedrasantiguasreescribenlahistoria-2173532/|title=Piedras antiguas reescriben la historia|author=Gerardo E. Alvarado León|publisher=''[[El Nuevo Día]]''|language=Spanish|date=2016-04-18|accessdate=2016-03-13}}</ref> Among those that inquired on the matter was ethnographer [[Alphonse Pinart]], who examined the pieces and concluded that they were "undoubtedly authentic".<ref name="ENDI"/> The explorer also expressed concern that some people could try to falsify pieces to receive gifts in exchange from them.<ref name="ENDI"/> Locally, historians took an interest in the matter while archeologists did not study them for decades.<ref name="NC"/> After the death of Nazario, most pieces were kept at the [[Institute of Puerto Rican Culture]] (ICP), with others being kept by the UPR and foreign institutions in New York, Spain and Paris.<ref name="ENDI"/><ref name="Interes"/> During the 1980s, the Collection attracted historian Salvador Tío, who tried to recruit a variety of institutions to the cause of studying the pieces.
During the 2010s, the study of the pieces has been taken by personnel of the archeology department of the [[University of Puerto Rico]] [[University of Puerto Rico at Utuado|at Utuado]]. Head archeologist Reniel Rodríguez decided to follow the scientific method to test several characteristics of the rocks and petroglyphs.<ref name="ENDI"/> Among these are geological studies, which concluded that the petroglyphs were carved in Puerto Rico and that the rocks were likely not brought from abroad based on the raw materials used, serpentine rocks found near location of the discovery.<ref name="ENDI"/> Another aspect of Rodríguez's research is based on using high power microscopes to determine the technique and instruments used to make the carvings, thus allowing for the detection of fraud if the tools are found not to have been available during the time.<ref name="ENDI"/> Preliminary results from this area suggest that the technique used was unlike any of the ones used by the known native groups of Puerto Rico.<ref name="ENDI"/> A new epigraphic study is also being conducted to determine the precedence of the petroglyphs or their closest parallels.<ref name="ENDI"/> Preliminary results in this area have found similarities between the petroglyphs and the [[Tifinagh#Origins|Libyco-Berber]] alphabet as recorded in the [[Canary Islands]] and the [[Tartessian language]] of the Iberian Peninsula.<ref name="ENDI"/> During this research, Rodríguez has recruited experts from [[Universidad del Turabo]] and [[University of Miami]].<ref name="ENDI"/> Additional studies planned include C-14 dating and thermoluminescence tests for burned pieces.<ref name="ENDI"/>
==Discovery and relocation== ===Exploration at Río Coayuco=== [[File:José María Nazario y Cancel.jpg|thumb|José M. Nazario in clergical clothing.]] The discovery of the rocks is attributed to Catholic priest José María Nazario y Cancel, a native of the municipality of [[Sabana Grande, Puerto Rico|Sabana Grande]] that had settled in Guayanilla and had received education at the [[University of Salamanca]] that included, among other things, the study of ancient languages.<ref name="ENDI"/>{{efn|Nazario was first appointed priest of Guayanilla in 1866, serving the office for 46 years.<ref name="EVT">{{cite web|url=http://www.elvisitante.biz/new/component/content/article/54-tu-revista-es-vida/886-la-gesta-cultural-del-padre-nazario|title=La gesta cultural del padre Nazario|publisher=''El Visitante''|language=Spanish|date=2012-03-08|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> He was known for his archeological and philosophical research and a particular interest in the influence of the Agüeybaná dynasty in the Caribbean.<ref name="EVT"/> Nazario was also an author and published ''Guayanilla y la Historia de Puerto Rico'', in which he analyzed the second voyage of [[Christopher Columbus]] and cited evidence for the likelihood that the municipality was the landing point of this expedition at Puerto Rico.<ref name="EVT"/>}} The popular story of the event was told by the priest to historian [[Adolfo de Hostos]].<ref name="EVT"/><ref name="PV">{{cite web|url=http://periodicovision.com/buscan-conocer-origen-de-piedras-del-padre-nazario/|title=Buscan conocer origen de piedras del padre Nazario|publisher=''Periódico Visión''|language=Spanish|date=2015-09-09|accessdate=2016-06-04}}</ref> According to this narrative, sometime during the late 1870s the minister was summoned to the deathbed of a local woman of [[Taíno]] ascent.<ref name="EVT"/> There she, who was aware of Nazario's interest in archeology and native history, decided to reveal the location of a long-hidden collection of artifacts.<ref name="NC">{{cite web|url=http://www.noticel.com/noticia/189148/piedras-antiguas-de-guayanilla-podrian-alterar-la-historia-oficial.html|title=Piedras antiguas de Guayanilla podrían alterar la historia oficial|author=Gabriela Saker Jímenez|publisher=[[NotiCel]]|language=Spanish|date=2016-04-16|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> This knowledge had been covertly passed from generation to generation throughout the centuries, but she decided to reveal it in hopes that the priest would recognize its historical importance and safeguard it from that point on.<ref name="PV"/> With time, the old woman was given the name of "Juana Morales" and was claimed to be "the last descendant" of [[Agüeybaná II]] or Agüeybaná El Bravo, the last ruler of the Puerto Rico natives and military leader during the [[Spanish–Taíno War of San Juan–Borikén]] (from whom the rocks get one of their colloquial namesakes), elements that were not found in the original version.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> There is no record of an elder person by that name dying during the time in the municipality’s records, but there is a local Morales family that lives at Barrio Indio and has its own oral tradition of the events dating back to at least the 1970s.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
Nazario then traveled between municipalities until he arrived at a riverside location in what is now speculated to have been the modern barrio Los Indios, reaching a stone slab that was meant as a marker.<ref name="NC"/> Digging the terrain, the priest found a tunnel and continued rummaging until he reached an alcove within which were more than 800 rocks and stones of varying sizes several of which had anthropomorphic shape, all covered in unknown petroglyphs that did not match any Amerindian civilization known to have lived in Puerto Rico or the Caribbean.<ref name="Coll">{{cite book|title=Cayetano Coll y Toste: Síntesis de estímulos humanos|chapter=El Padre Nazario|author=Edna Coll|publisher=Editorial Universitaria (University of Puerto Rico)|language=Spanish|year=1970|pages=68}}</ref> From 1880 onwards, the rocks were taken to Nazario's personal house at Guayanilla, not the parochial house, where he kept the other fragments of this finding and several other archeological pieces as part of his collection.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>{{efn|The structure was worth 250 Spanish pesos and he established an impromptu museum within it.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>}} Nazario gave the people involved in the extraction a modest reward for bringing pieces there.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In 1883, [[Agustín Stahl]] and [[Román Baldorioty de Castro]] visited the house and discussed the possibility of creating the Puerto Rico Museum of Natural History.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
===Early research=== Nazario named them ''antropoglifitas'' (hispanized from the Greek "antropōmorphos", which relates to having human-like characteristics, and "gluphē", which refers to carvings) and considered each individual piece a volume in a larger story.<ref name="antropoglifitas"/> In his writings, Nazario stated that they had been found packed in a small area and at a distance that was "not extraordinarily away from Guayanilla", speculating if they had been hidden there to avoid being lost at war (between the local and foreign natives) due to its proximity to the chiefdom of Agüeybaná.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The priest was close to physician and author [[Manuel Zeno Gandía]], with whom he exchanged correspondence and would later join him in a historical debate over the location of Columbus' arrival to Puerto Rico.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Nazario gave him two pieces of the Collection to him and requested that they were kept safe and close.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In 1881, when Zeno Gandía was chosen as representative of the Puerto Rican media in the activities held to commemorate [[Pedro Calderón de la Barca]]'s second centenary in Spain, he took the pieces to the founder of the [[Museo Nacional de Antropología (Madrid)|Museo Nacional de Antropología]], Pedro González de Velasco, who according to the author insisted in keeping one of them.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> An agreement was reached between both, where the Spaniard accepted naming it after Nazario and gave credit to its discovery in Puerto Rico.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> This event caused a temporary estrangement between Zeno Gandía and the priest.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> After González de Velasco died the following year, the destination of the piece became unknown.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
The first formal mention of the Collection was made by Alphonse Pinart in 1890, noting that the discovery was made near Yauco, in a place that he identifies as "Hanoa, Puerto Rico", and that some pieces displayed signs of being "undoubtedly authentic", but assumed that unscrupulous people fabricated their own to receive a reward.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> He further noted similarities between the characters in the Collection and known ancient alphabets, but declined speculating further on the matter.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Pinart also embarked some pieces with him to the [[Musée d'Ethnographie du Trocadéro]] from which they were moved to the [[Musée du quai Branly]] when the former institution closed down, 38 pieces remain there and form the largest known concentration outside of Puerto Rico.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Nazario later noted that besides France, other pieces had been taken by the researcher to Copenhagen and Philadelphia.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
In 1893, Nazario wrote a piece named ''Escritura Aborigen de Carib'' (English: "Aboriginal writing of the Carib"), where he detailed his interpretations of the petroglyphs.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>{{efn|"Carib" was the term used by Nazario when discussing the Taíno.<ref name="antropoglifitas"/>}} Analyzing the inscriptions, he dismissed a Taíno or [[Arawak]] origin and by 1897 had concluded that the carvings were more reminiscent of [[Chaldean Neo-Aramaic|Chaldean]] or [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] languages, saying that he recognized some of the characters present.<ref name="EV">{{cite web|url=http://elvocero.com/las-piedras-antiguas-de-guayanilla-una-historia-que-puede-cambiar-la-historia/|title=Las piedras antiguas de Guayanilla: una historia que puede cambiar….la historia|author=Ileanexis Vera Rosado|publisher=''[[El Vocero]]''|language=Spanish|date=2016-04-18|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> Nazario also asserted that based on the study of the petroglyphs, it was safe to conclude that the Pre-Columbian inhabitants of Puerto Rico had perfected writing beyond the natives of Mexico or Peru, speculating that the pieces could have been a Pre-Columbian national archive of some kind.<ref name="antropoglifitas">{{cite book|title=Guayanilla y la historia de Puerto Rico|author=José María Nazario y Cancel|chapter=Prueba directa del arribaje de Colón en Guayanilla, deducidas las huellas de un pueblo caribitano fundado en la Playa. Residencia del cacique Augueybana.|publisher=Impresora de la Revista de Puerto Rico|language=Spanish|year=1893|pages=139}}</ref> Nazario would then begin an effort to translate the characters phonetically after acquiring a copy of 1889's ''Historia De Las Naciones: Caldea'' (English: "History of the Nations: Chaldea") and using the characters present in a Babylonian religious artifact reproduced there.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The document would be modified and later become known as ''Escritura Fonética de los Indios de Puerto Rico'' (English: "Phonetic orthography of the Indians of Puerto Rico").<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Nazario hypothesized that perceived linguistic similarities could imply that some of the [[Ten Lost Tribes]] crossed Asia making their way into the [[Bering Strait]] and traveled from there to North America, before dividing somewhere near Central America, from where they arrived to the Caribbean.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
The conclusions reached by Nazario were met with skepticism by mainstream archeologists who labeled him as "imaginative [and/or] crazy",<ref name="2008exhibition"/> as it implied contact with the New World prior to Columbus' voyages, and speculation emerged that he had paid a local [[jíbaro]] (a class of Puerto Rican countrymen) to sculpt the stones with a machete and that the petroglyphs were meaningless. In 1894, Nazario met [[Cayetano Coll y Toste]], which whom he had been involved in a number of historical debates, at San Juan.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Both discussed the possibility of the historian aiding in the process of deciphering the characters in the Collection, but the effort was aborted when the condition of sending the pieces to San Juan (to be returned later) was proposed.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> According to historian Otto Sievens, several of the rocks were thrown into a cistern at Guayanilla's church when the Americans arrived during the [[Spanish–American War]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.periodicolaperla.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5172:la-historia-se-reescribe-con-las-piedras-de-guayanilla&catid=119:articulos&Itemid=342|title=Piedras de Guayanilla reescriben historia|author=Hector Sánchez|publisher=''[[La Perla del Sur]]''|language=Spanish|date=2013-06-12|accessdate=2016-05-31}}</ref> By 1903, Nazario was holding conferences about the Collection, which were unsuccessful in gaining the desired attention.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
That same year, [[Jesse Walter Fewkes]] of the [[Smithsonian Institution]], visited Puerto Rico and reportedly offered Nazario $800 to buy the pieces, but the offer was declined.<ref name="ENDI"/> In his subsequent report, the anthropologist concluded that the assemblage was the most intricate one among those that gathered native petroglyphs in Puerto Rico.<ref name="Fewkes">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/annualreportofbu0v25powe/annualreportofbu0v25powe_djvu.txt|title=Annual report of the Bureau of ethnology to the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution|author=John Wesley Powell|publisher=[[Internet Archive]]|year=1907}}</ref> However, in his examination of the carvings Fewkes also commented that the inscriptions were not Amerindian in origin and labeled them as "exotic", leading to an assumption that they may not be ancient.<ref name="Fewkes"/> In his field notes, Fewkes notes that he was unable to find Nazario during a first visit in 1902, returning the following year.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> He also stated that the entire Collection was under a roof, that the pieces were classified by priority, and that the priest gave him his writings (which he discarded as not being authored by a scientist).<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Despite his skepticism, Fewkes took some pieces with him, which he placed in an exhibit along pieces of dubious origin at the [[National Museum of Natural History]] based on his initial assessment.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> This led to unrelated American archeologists assuming that the rocks were a forgery, discontinuing their investigation for several decades.<ref name="ENDI"/> Influenced by their foreign peer, local archeologists also lost interest in the Collection and stopped their inquiry for decades.<ref name="ENDI"/>
In an interview held in 1905, the priest showed ''Escritura Fonética de los Indios de Puerto Rico'' to journalist Gabriel A. Piles and discussed hypotheses about the arrival of Old World travelers as well as his efforts to translate the characters using ''Historia De Las Naciones: Caldea''.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Between 1911 and 1912, Nazario was transferred to San Juan while facing health issues. After being relocated, the priest had the Collection moved to the capital and kept it in his room.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In 1908, Nazario wrote to Zeno Gandía informing him that a letter from Pinart had arrived, in the process making a throwaway remark noting that "it was almost incredible that 28 years [had already passed since their first meeting]", which would later allow to date the philologist's visit to 1880 and placed the original date of discovery sometime during the late 1870s.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>{{efn|Nazario had been moved away from Guayanilla for some time, so the discovery had to take place between his return to the office in 1875 and Pinart's visit in 1880.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>}} During this decade, [[Samuel Kirkland Lothrop]] visited Puerto Rico and took some pieces.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
Archeologist [[Adolfo de Hostos]] visited Nazario in San Juan, where he was told the now-popular origin story.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Taking some pieces with him, Hostos was still not convinced that the Collection (which at this point he estimates rounds the 700 pieces) possessed cuneiform characters, but still felt that it required detailed study.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> With the death of Nazario in 1919, the pieces became segregated, with only around 250 being acquired by collector Robert Junhans and later preserved at the [[Institute of Puerto Rican Culture]].<ref name="ENDI"/><ref name="Interes"/> The first pieces arrived there during the 1950s, where they were placed in storage.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The pieces in Hostos possession were granted to the University of Puerto Rico.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> These were relocated to the Museo de Historia, Antropología y Arte at Río Piedras.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The ones owned by Lothrop were sent to the [[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology]].<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Alice de Santiago, a school teacher from Barceloneta, reportedly found a piece that was similar to those in possession of Nazario but made in limestone and contacted Zeno Gandía.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The current whereabouts of this rock are unknown.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
A number of writings authored by Nazario where later recovered by Zeno Gandía, who republished them in ''[[El Imparcial]]'' and claimed that he had seen Martin J. Berntsen of the Dominican priests of Bayamon taking some of the documents once his friend died, with the documents later being found by a priest in the parochial archives there.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The origin story was first published by Hostos more than three decades later in 1955, having already deviated slightly from its original account by integrating elements related to the adaptation of the account to then-concurrent concepts.<ref name="CEAPRC">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rZECSNhTyhU&app=desktop|title=Reniel Rodríguez Ramos: Piedras Padre Nazario|publisher=Centro de Estudios Avanzados de Puerto Rico y el Caribe (official YouTube channel)|language=Spanish|date=2016-05-22|accessdate=2016-07-01}}</ref> In it, he discussed a booklet filled with notes from Nazario being the last known person to be see the lost document.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
==Media exposure== ===Late 20th century=== In 1969, Hostos sent one of the pieces to the [[British Museum]] so that it could be studied by scholar C.B.F. Walker, author of a number of books on cuneiform writing.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Afterwards, Walker responded with an assessment that it possessed characteristics similar to pieces recorded circa 2000 B.C. and that it could be Sumerian in origin.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> During the 1980s, the president of the ''Academia Puertorriqueña de la Historia'' (English: "Puerto Rican Academy of History") Aurelio Tió revived the debate surrounding the pieces and began insisting on the thorough study of the inscriptions, citing that the idea that they were randomly inscribed with a machete was implausible.<ref name="NC"/> This historian dismissed the prevailing conclusions surrounding the rocks, noting that too much emphasis had been given to Fewkes' insinuation and that, despite the lack of formal studies by the anthropologist, it had somehow become widely accepted among local archeologists.<ref>{{cite book|title=Boletín de la Academia Puertorriqueña de la Historia, vol. 6|chapter=Las antropoglifitas del Padre Nazario y su possible relación con el predominio del cacicazgo de Guaybana|author=Aurelio Tío|publisher=Academia Puertorriqueña de la Historia|date=Jul 1980|pages=24}}</ref> Tío argued that if authenticated, the Collection could potentially represent one of the biggest archeological finds in the Americas and the Western Hemisphere, a position that he defended until his death.<ref name="Interes">{{cite web|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/entretenimiento/cultura/nota/altointeresporlaspiedrasantiguasdeguayanilla-2194592/|title=Alto interés por las piedras antiguas de Guayanilla|publisher=''[[El Nuevo Día]]''|language=Spanish|date=2016-05-03|accessdate=2016-06-04}}</ref><ref name="PV"/> He unsuccessfully tried encouraging the Smithsonian, [[Harvard University]], [[University of Valladolid]], [[Yale University]], [[University of Pennsylvania]], the [[British Museum]] and archeologist Marcel Sigrist to retake the study of the pieces.<ref name="PLP">{{cite web|url=http://www.periodicolaperla.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5154:aunque-muchos-lo-nieguen-ila-clave-esta-en-guayanilla&catid=119:articulos&Itemid=342|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105093402/http://www.periodicolaperla.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5154:aunque-muchos-lo-nieguen-ila-clave-esta-en-guayanilla&catid=119:articulos&Itemid=342|title=Guayanilla: pieza clave de nuestra historia|author=Hector Sánchez|publisher=''[[La Perla del Sur]]''|language=Spanish|date=2013-06-05|archivedate=2003-11-05|accessdate=2018-03-23}}</ref> In total, Tío wrote over 30 papers on the Collection evaluating its potential significance to local history and the possible influence on the Taíno population, which did not receive academic examination or rebuttals from the archeological community.<ref name="NC"/><ref name="ENDI"/> He also commissioned a professional photographer to capture the first high quality images of the pieces, which were to be re-published in the media.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Linguists from Spain, Portugal, Switzerland and France were involved in the issue, with the latter concluding that they could be legitimate.<ref name="ENDI"/><ref name="2008exhibition"/>
===Phoenician hypothesis=== Despite not meeting with immediate success, the attempt to bring the topic to the mainstream did gather the interest of peripheral groups such as the Midwestern Epigraphic Society, which considered the pieces authentic in a report and established parallels between the symbols present in the petroglyphs and similar inscriptions present in cooper and gold slabs recovered in Ecuador.<ref name="Fell">{{cite book|title=Epigraphic Society Occasional Publications, Vol. 16|author=Barry Fell|chapter=Inscribed Stone Artifacts from Guayanilla, Puerto Rico|publisher=Midwestern Epigraphic Society|year=1987|pages=322}}</ref> Author [[Barry Fell]] concluded that the inscriptions were not random, and that the characters correspond to Pre-Greek characters found in Cyprus, Turkey and Crete, rearranged so that they would be phonetically read in Pre-Incan [[Quechuan languages|Quechuan]].<ref name="Fell"/> The speculation being that ancient Cyprians had previously interacted with the South American ethnic group and learned to write that language with their alphabet before reaching Puerto Rico and doing the same with the local population.<ref name="Fell"/> According to Fell, evidence suggesting the authenticity of the petroglyphs emerged with the discovery (along the relevant civilization) of a similar grid-based and acrostic language by Pedro I. Porrás Garcés at Ecuador in 1961, which was first detailed in his an article titled "Arqueología de la Región Oriental" (English: "Archeology of the Oriental Region").<ref name="Fell"/> The document also notes similarities with characters present in the royal robe of [[Viracocha Inca]], leading to the hypothesis that they were [[huaca]]s and that one particular piece was dedicated to a request to Mamai, the title invested to the Incan queen.<ref name="Fell"/> Fell concludes that the Collection would represent the largest finding related to this culture and the only one outside South America.<ref name="Fell"/> The report gathered some interest, but conflicting views within the mainstream media resulted in stagnation of the topic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://personal.isla.net/cronista/el_padre.htm |title=El Padre Nazario: A 166 años de su natalicio |author=Norberto Lugo Negrón |publisher=''Periódico Regional El Cronista'' |language=Spanish |date=September 2004 |accessdate=June 4, 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131071945/http://personal.isla.net/cronista/el_padre.htm |archivedate=January 31, 2009 }}</ref>
===Public exhibitions=== After the death of Salvador Tió, others that have promoted the topic include Antonio Molina and his daughter, Zoé Tió.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In Guayanilla, biographer Norbeto Lugo and Irvin Sepúlveda have made efforts to foment the study on the pieces.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In 2008, interest in the pieces surrounded the 175th Anniversary of the municipality's foundation.<ref name="2008exhibition"/> It was due to this celebration, where interest in Guayanilla's history peaked, that arrangements were made to have the Collection in public exhibition for the first time and the first time in decades that the topic returned to the mainstream media.<ref name="2008exhibition">{{cite web|url=http://www.primerahora.com/noticias/isla/nota/exponenpiedrasdelpadrenazario-161850/|title=Exponen Piedras del padre Nazario|publisher=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|language=Spanish|date=2008-02-25|accessdate=2016-06-04}}</ref> The exhibition took place between March 27 and 28 at the behest of Leandro Hernández, director of the ''Centro Cultural María Arzola'' (English: "María Arzola Cultural Center") which also hosted the pieces.<ref name="2008exhibition"/> The municipal administration of Guayanilla then announced arrangements to have them permanently moved there in order to exhibit them.<ref name="2008exhibition"/> During the following year, interest in the Collection grew and the municipality began efforts to create the ''Museo de Epigrafía Lítica Padre Nazario'' (English: "Father Nazario Museum of Lithic Epigraphy") to emphasize them.<ref name="Museo2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/entretenimiento/cultura/nota/porlapreservaciondelaarqueologia-613075/|title=Por la preservación de la arqueología|publisher=''[[El Nuevo Día]]''|language=Spanish|date=2009-09-09|accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, the finding became a central argument against the creation of an eolic park in the region.<ref name="Museo2009"/> Upon opening, the museum featured a permanent exhibition where 19 pieces of the Collection were on display, among other archeological exhibitions relevant to the municipality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:KWHVpi_d6R8J:www.periodicolaperla.com/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26view%3Darticle%26id%3D6182%26Itemid%3D342&num=1&hl=en&gl=pr&strip=1&vwsrc=0|title=Exposición colectiva digna de admiración|author=Reinaldo Millán|publisher=''[[La Perla del Sur]]''|language=Spanish|date=2014-06-18|accessdate=2016-06-04}}</ref> The topic re-entered the mainstream media in April 2016, with coverage related to a conference covering his research that was organized by Zoé Tió.<ref name="NC"/>
==Recent research== ===Studies on composition and characteristics===
In 2012, research on the pieces returned to the mainstream academia with the involvement of Reniel Rodríguez Ramos from the [[University of Puerto Rico at Utuado]], who was concerned that up to that point most of the local research had been carried by historians.<ref name="NC"/>{{efn|Rodríguez is a lithic artifact expert and Ripley B. Bullen Award winner for "Outstanding Research in Caribbean Archaeology".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cohemis.uprm.edu/espa/docs/Vita_RenielRodriguez.pdf|title=Reniel Rodríguez: Ramos Programa de Ciencias Sociales Universidad de Puerto Rico Recinto de Utuado|publisher=[[University of Puerto Rico at Utuado]]|language=Spanish|accessdate=2016-06-04}}</ref>}} During his first visit to the ICP, he encountered part of the Collection being repurposed and the rest in storage.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> While attending an activity in the British Museum in 2014, Rodríguez took some pieces with him to the cuneiform exhibit, where he was casually presented to C.B.F. Walker while showing [[Jago Cooper]] a copy of Hostos' letter to the now-retired cuneiform expert.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> None of the present gave a definitive answer to their nature, but agreed that further study was needed.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Parallel to this process, a documentary began being prepared by cinematographer Carlos García in collaboration with Rodríguez and his team.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
In terms of characteristics, most pieces depict individuals in what appear to be varying ceremonial postures while wearing headwear and a tunic in which the petroglyphs are present.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The group also examined other characters that deviated from the norm, such as those present at a site within the [[Guánica State Forest]] in an attempt to identify similar inscriptions.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In relation to local natives, analogues are scarce and not identical, with some a similar headwear appearing in a piece unearthed at Tecla in Guayanilla and elements of clothing in idols (and additional symbols) being found at La Hueca in Vieques.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Rodríguez has been unable to pinpoint the place referred to as "Hanoa, Puerto Rico" in Pinart's notes.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Consequently, the research team carried sample collection in the south western coast of Puerto Rico, in particular the regions of Guayanilla and Yauco assumed to be near the initial discovery, such as Barrio Los Indios and Barina.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> After completing macroscopic examination, the prime matter is consonant with serpentinized peridotite with traces of bastite and mica typical in the region.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
Efforts were made by the research team to retrieve as much firsthand information on the origin and history of the pieces as possible.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> With the collaboration of Laura Rodríguez from the [[Bayamón Central University]], the archeologist was able to rummage through the Zeno Gandía Collection (a repository of documents and artifacts that used to belong to him) and retrieve the correspondence between Nazario and the author.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> By establishing the date of Pinart's first visit, Rodríguez attempted to prove if Nazario had access to sources detailing ancient writing similar to that exhibited in the Collection prior to this.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In this regard, he concluded that since ''Historia De Las Naciones: Caldea'' was published at least nine years after the visit of Pinart, it could not have been used by Nazario to forge the characters.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> He also acquired Fewke's field notes with the help of Roberto Martínez.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Rodríguez tried to pinpoint the location of González de Velasco's piece, but was told that it is no longer part of the Museo Nacional de Antropología's Puerto Rico exhibit.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
The archeologist discussed how to proceed with people from a number of fields, including geology, chemistry and physics.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> To determine the chemical characteristics of the pieces, Antonio Martínez of the Physics Department of the UPR and Pablo Llerandi of General Studies at [[University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras Campus]] (UPR-RP) have been involved in an initiative to complete studies on X-ray diffraction and spectrography, in order to further pinpoint the properties of the prime matter.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In order to determine the characteristics of the traces the high power microscopes of the UPR-RP were used to carry out high magnification studies in which perpendicular striations were noted as part of a pointer drag technique.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Some pieces do display characters that were added later than those in the others, implying that some were created afterwards.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> However, the manner in which some of the pieces have been [[erosion|intemperized]] (in particular the presence of differential intemperization in some that has rounded the edges of fractures in only one of the sides) is inconsistent with them being fabrications that were forged in the late 1870s and then stored indoors ever since, instead suggesting that they were exposed to the elements for a prolonged time period.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Further efforts are being made to fund a collaboration with [[Leiden University]] to advance this research area with their specialists.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
Carlos Silva of [[Universidad del Turabo]] has been involved in the 3D scanning of the pieces.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The high definition imaging has led to the interest of philologist [[Christopher Rollston]], whom Rodríguez considers a candidate to attempt the falsification of the Old World hypothesis.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Studies in thermoluminescence have been proposed to establish the last time that the rocks were set on fire.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Some of the artifacts were burned after the traces were made, with the pieces that fragmented during the process being plausible candidates.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Others have carbon remnants that could be dated by employing the C-14 method.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> The general plan is to send separate pieces to the [[University of Washington]] Luminescence Dating Laboratory and to Oxford Authentication to compare results, which Rodríguez considers possibly conclusive.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Towards this end, he has requested additional support from the ICP or the Official Historian of Puerto Rico.<ref name="ENDI"/>
===Potential hypotheses=== Based on his research, Rodríguez has formulated a number of hypotheses that are being currently examined without taking an a priori position about their authenticity or the possibility of fraud, with his initial position taking under consideration that some pieces where likely created after the initial discovery.<ref name="ENDI"/><ref name="Interes"/> If the entire Collection is proven to be fraudulent, he argues that the age of the pieces makes them archeological artifacts in their own right.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Rodríguez has also formulated a preliminary hypothesis if several of the pieces are certified as authentic, for which he tried to identify similar geodesic characters, since these are not common, and have only been found in the Caribbean at [[Mona Island]], Salto Arriba in Puerto Rico, Bateyes de Viví in Cuba and Piedra Mapa in Santa Marta.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Throughout the rest of the globe, their closest analogues are found at the [[Canary Islands]].<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Rodríguez also considers that religious idols found in this archipelago exhibit similar posture and facial features, which were not discovered until after the pieces were reportedly unearthed and he argues that Nazario could not have known.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> In terms of character analysis, there are some that are analogue to the [[Tifinagh#Origins|Libyco-Berber]] alphabet found in the Canary Islands.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
After the initial studies, a set of cave paintings was uncovered near Playa Los Tubos, which Rodríguez decided to capture and send to Renata Springer Bunk (a philologist who has authored several books about the Libyco-Berber characters at the Canary Islands) who responded in the affirmative about their nature but lost interest after being told that they were found at Puerto Rico.<ref name="CEAPRC"/> Ultimately, he combined these with the seafaring nature of Caribbean natives and studies like one in which archeologist Richard Thomas Callahan of the [[University of Calgary]] studied how far the [[Canary Current]] could have dragged a drifting vessel, to formulate a hypothesis that he wants to falsify.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>{{efn|Callahan has studied the topic and published papers on his research, including a 2015 article titled "Drift Voyages across the Mid-Atlantic".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=9756298|title=Drift voyages across the mid-Atlantic|author=Richard T. Callaghan|publisher=''[[Antiquity (journal)|Antiquity]]''|date=June 2015|accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>}} In regards to other hypotheses, Rodríguez is skeptical of Fell's conclusion and notes that some of the words that the zoologist translated as phonetic Quechan such as ''yuca'', ''ungey'', ''chayote'' or ''papaya'' are in fact Arawak in origin.<ref name="CEAPRC"/>
==Notes== {{notelist|30em}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Archaeology of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Indigenous sculpture of the Americas]] [[Category:Pre-Columbian art]] [[Category:Rock art in North America]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2017}}
An '''online book''' is a resource in [[book]]-like form that is only available to read on the [[Internet]]. It differs from the common idea of an [[e-book]], which is usually available for users to download and read locally on a computer, [[smartphone]] or on an [[e-reader]]. "Book-like" means: information is presented in a page format; pages are normally available to read sequentially (though "flipping" to another page is possible using a mouse, keyboard or other controllers); and pages are read passively, with little or no interaction or multimedia. This contrasts with a text which a user is reading on an interactive [[Web 2.0]] website, which usually enables the user to click on online links, look up words or keywords online, etc. "Online" means the content may only be read while the reader is connected to the Internet. Thus the reader's experience with an online book is similar to reading a printed book, except that the book is read at a computer and is only accessible while the reader is online.
Online books are a common resource in [[virtual learning environment]]s (VLEs). For example, the [[Moodle]] VLE defines an online book in this way. Over the last few years, there has been an increase of online books that are being used for notable events or to commemorate the memory of someone. The fundraising industry often uses online books as a way to fundraise, as online books are also a way to collect donations and engage with their audience.
==See also== * [[Electronic journal]] *[[Internet Public Library]] *[[Online Books Page]] *[[Online magazine]] *[[Online newspaper]] *[[Project Gutenberg]] *[[Web fiction]] *[[Webserial]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Electronic publishing]] [[Category:New media]] [[Category:Digital media]]
{{publishing-stub}} {{Web-stub}}

{{Infobox artist | name = Oreet Ashery | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{bya|1966}} | birth_place = [[Jerusalem, Israel]] | education = [[Sheffield Hallam University]], [[Central Saint Martins]] }}
'''Oreet Ashery''' (born 1966 in [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]]) is an Israeli interdisciplinary artist based in [[London]].<ref name=EASCFA>{{cite web|title=Oreet |url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/gallery/oreet_ashery.php|work=Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art: Feminist Art Base|publisher=Brooklyn Museum|accessdate=2 April 2014}}</ref>
==Career== Ashery received her BA (distinction) in [[Fine Art]] from [[Sheffield Hallam University]] in 1992, followed by her MA in Fine Arts from [[Central Saint Martins]] in 2000. Her work explores ideological, social and gender constructions through an interdisciplinary practice, spanning [[Installation art|installation]], [[Video art|video]], [[Performance art|live art]] and 2-D image making.
Ashery's earlier work was often produced as a male character of her own creation, exploring [[Gender role|gender relationships]] and those between woman and cultural identity.<ref>http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/gallery/oreet_ashery.php</ref> Ashery's most consistent character is Marcus Fisher, an [[orthodox Jewish]] man<ref name=Reilly>{{cite journal|last=Reilly|first=Maura|title=Curating Transnational Feminisms|journal=Feminist Studies|volume=36|series=RETHINKING THE GLOBAL|issue=1|pages=171}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Jacobs|first=Katrien|title=Hong Kong Screenscapes: From the New Wave to the Digital Frontier|date=2011|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|location=Hong Kong|isbn=9789888028566|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-pLCZq_TKRwC&lpg=PA226&dq=Oreet%20Ashery&pg=PA226#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=On Isaac Leung, Cyber Sex as Pseudo-Science}}</ref> found in works such as ''Dancing with Men'' and ''Marcus Fisher | Say Cheese'', but she has produced as other male characters, including an Arab man, a Norwegian postman and a black man.<ref>http://www.artangel.org.uk//projects/2010/staying/about_oreet_ashery/oreet_ashery</ref>
Ashery's more recent work has been based on [[Vladimir Mayakovsky|Mayakovsky]]'s 1921 play ''[[Mystery-Bouffe]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oreet Ashery's Party for Freedom|url=http://www.gold.ac.uk/visual-cultures/calendar/?id=6519|website=Department of Visual Cultures: Archived Event|publisher=Goldsmiths, University of London|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> This work confronts social and class biases alongside issues of political power and agency. Her performance at the [[Tate Modern]] ''The World is Flooding'' in 2014 was followed by an exhibition ''Animal with a Language'' at Waterside Contemporary, both of which saw Ashery work with participants from [[Freedom from Torture]], UK Lesbian and Gay Immigration Group, Portugal Prints,<ref>http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-modern/performance-and-music/world-flooding</ref> and others, to explore these themes.
Ashery has exhibited and performed at various international venues, such as [[Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe|ZKM]], [[Karlsruhe]]; [[Haus der Kulturen der Welt]], Berlin; [[Brooklyn Museum]], [[New York City|New York]]; Overgaden, [[Copenhagen]]; DEPO, [[Istanbul]]; Whitstable Biennale; [[Centre Georges Pompidou|Centre Pompidou]], Paris; [[Auto Italia South East]], London; and [[Freud Museum]], London,<ref name="oreetashery.net">http://oreetashery.net/cv/</ref> producing works that explore her personal politics and identity in relation to wider social and cultural contexts.
== Awards == * 2014 Fine Art Fellowship, Stanley Picker Fellowship * 2013{{ndash}}2015 [[Visiting scholar|Visiting Professor]], [[Royal College of Art]], Painting Department * 2011{{ndash}}2014 Honorary Research Fellow, School of English and Drama, [[Queen Mary University of London]] * 2007{{ndash}}2010 [[Arts and Humanities Research Council]] Creative Research Fellow, Drama Department, Queen Mary University of London
==Solo exhibitions== ;2017-2018 *''Revisiting Genesis". 6th Thessaloniki Biennale of Contemporary Art
;2016 *''Revisiting Genesis''. Stanley Picker Gallery, Kingston, UK *''Revisiting Genesis''. Tyneside Cinema, UK
; ;2015 *''Oreet Ashery''. Revisiting Genesis, fig-2, ICA, London, UK *''Animal with a Language''. Champagne Premiere, Berlin, Germany
;2014 *''Animal with a Language''. Waterside Contemporary, London, UK
;2013 *''Party for Freedom''. Hippolythe, [[Helsinki]], Finland *''Party for Freedom''. Overgaden, Copenhagen, Denmark
;2012 *''Monkey Bum Prints Factory''. Pristine Gallery, Mexico{{where|date=December 2014}} *''Oreet Ashery'', with Nicole Ahland. C. Wichtendahl. Galerie, 5th European Month of Photography, Berlin, Germany
;2011 *''Falafel Road'', with [[Larissa Sansour]]. DEPO, Istanbul, Turkey
;2010 *''The Beautiful Jew''. Other Gallery, [[Shanghai]], China *''Raging Balls''. Other Gallery, [[Beijing]], China
;2009 *''Back in 5 Minutes'' and ''Scratch Performance: Golani Varanasi''. [[The Arches (Glasgow)|The Arches]], Glasgow, UK
;2008 *''Dancing with Men''. Sherwell Centre, [[Plymouth University]], [[Plymouth]], UK
;2007 *''What You See'', Letchworth Art Centre Gallery, [[Letchworth]], UK
;2003 *''Performance 2003''. Foxy Production Gallery, New York, US *''Say Cheese''. [[Bluecoat Chambers|Bluecoat Arts Centre]], [[Liverpool]], UK
;2002 *''Oreet Ashery''. Foxy Production Gallery, New York, US *''7 Acts of Love''. Kapelica Gallery, [[Ljubljana]], Slovenia *''7 Acts of Love''. Stil und Bruch, Berlin, Germany
;1998 *''Magnum Opus III'', with Daniel Rubinstein. Jerusalem Artists’ House Gallery, Jerusalem, Israel
;1996 *''Magnum Opus II'', with Daniel Rubinstein. 68elf Gallery, Cologne, Germany<ref name="oreetashery.net"/>

revision.comment: added [[Category:Jamaican emigrants to the United Kingdom]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''Patricia Cumper''', [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]], [[FRSA]] (born 1954), also known as '''Pat Cumper''', is a British playwright, producer, director, theatre administrator, critic and commentator.<ref name=govt2013>{{cite web|title=Government appointments|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/the-prime-minister-has-appointed-four-trustees-to-the-board-of-the-british-museum|accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=histbio>{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Marjorie|title=Biography - Patricia Cumper|url=http://historicalgeographies.blogspot.co.uk/2011/09/biography-patricia-cumper.html|work=Historical Geographies|accessdate=10 March 2014|date=22 September 2011}}</ref>
==Life== Cumper grew up in [[Jamaica]], with her English father and Jamaican mother. She followed her parents to study at [[Cambridge University]], for which she won a scholarship from [[Queen's School, Jamaica|The Queen's School]] in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]], to study Archaeology and Anthropology at [[Girton College, Cambridge|Girton College]] (1973–76).<ref>[https://www.artsprofessional.co.uk/magazine/241/job-ladder "Patricia Cumper shares the route she took to her current role"], ''Arts Professional'', 29 August 2011.</ref> While there, Cumper was a College Exhibitioner and was also awarded a full swimming [[Blue (university sport)#University of Cambridge|Blue]], captaining the swim team.<ref name=govt2013 /><ref name=histbio /><ref name=afrizidiak>{{cite web|last=Jackson|first=Sophia|title=Patricia Cumper|url=http://www.afridiziak.com/theatrenews/interviews/may2011/patricia-cumper.html|work=Afrizidiak|accessdate=10 March 2014|date=3 May 2011}}</ref>
After graduating, Cumper returned to Jamaica, where she began a career writing for the radio, including two major soap operas, ''Malvina's Revenge'' and ''Mortimer Simmonds''.<ref name=Gleaner>[http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20160701/large-abroad-theatre-screenplay-jamaican-driving-caribbean-identity-uk "Large Abroad | From Theatre To Screenplay - Jamaican Driving Caribbean Identity In The UK"], ''[[Jamaica Gleaner|The Gleaner]]'', 1 July 2016.</ref> Returning to Britain in 1993 she continued her career as a playwright, writing for [[BBC Radio 4]].<ref name=bm>{{cite web|title=Trustee - Patricia Cumper|url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/about_us/management/trustees/patricia_cumper.aspx|accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=Gleaner />
In the [[2013 New Year Honours]] she was appointed a [[Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) for services to the arts.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gruner|first=Peter|title=Queen's New Year Honours – MBE salutes ‘inspirational’ creator of vibrant theatre |url=https://archive.islingtontribune.com/news/2013/jan/queens-new-year-honours-%E2%80%93-mbe-salutes-%E2%80%98inspirational%E2%80%99-creator-vibrant-theatre|accessdate=25 February 2018|newspaper=Islington Tribune|date=4 January 2013}}</ref>
She has sons and grandsons, whom she describes as "the great joys of her life".<ref name=bm />
==Career== Cumper has written a large number of plays both for the stage and radio, episodes of ''[[Westway (1997 radio series)|Westway]]'', short stories, and a novel, ''One Bright Child'', published in 1998.<ref name=writewords>{{cite web|title=Patricia Cumper Interview|url=http://www.writewords.org.uk/interviews/patricia_cumper.asp|work=WriteWords|accessdate=10 March 2014|date=6 April 2006}}</ref>
Cumper began writing after watching a play of which she was critical, and being challenged to do better. She wrote a play called ''The Rapist'', which ran for six months and won an award. She continued to write and also produced plays, winning four awards for her work, which was produced in the Caribbean, the USA and Canada. She moved to Britain in 1993 to pursue her career.<ref name=histbio /><ref name=bm />
Cumper worked for the UK's largest Black-led theatre company, [[Talawa Theatre Company|Talawa]], from about 1999, as a writer, script reader, tutor, assistant director and dramaturge.<ref name=bm /><ref name=writewords />
She became artistic director of Talawa in 2006 and stepped down in 2012, after overseeing their 25th anniversary season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Patricia Cumper ends five-year run at Talawa|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2011/06/patricia-cumper-ends-five-year-run-at-talawa/|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=The Stage|date=29 June 2011}}</ref>
Cumper became a [[List of trustees of the British Museum|trustee]] of the [[British Museum]] in 2013.<ref name=govt2013 />
In January 2015, her adaptation of [[Toni Morrison]]'s novel ''[[Beloved (novel)|Beloved]]'' was broadcast in 10 episodes by [[BBC Radio 4]] as part of its ''[[15 Minute Drama]]'' programme.<ref name="BBC Online">{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06tr5t3|title= 15 Minute Drama, Beloved Episode 1 of 10|author= | website= [[BBC Online]] |publisher= | accessdate= 4 January 2016 }}</ref>
Cumper's 2017 play ''Chigger Foot Boys'', which pays tribute to African and Caribbean soldiers who lost their lives in the [[First World War]], was produced at Tara Arts to a positive reception. Paul Vale in a four-star review for ''[[The Stage]]'' called it a "Richly textured play delivered with clarity and touchingly performed", commenting that "the perspective is wholly enlightening",<ref>[https://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/2017/chigger-foot-boys-review-tara-theatre-london/ "Chigger Foot Boys review at Tara Theatre, London – ‘richly textured’"], 27 February 2017.</ref> and Sonia Grant wrote in the ''[[Huffington Post]]'': "In the dexterous hands of acclaimed playwright Patricia Cumper MBE, Chigger Foot Boys accomplished what a good theatrical production should by being bold, entertaining and enlightening. Indeed, Cumper's year and a half's research in both Britain and Jamaica shows; the play is jam-packed with little-known information on Jamaica's involvement in World War I."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/sonia-grant/chigger-foot-boys-reviews_b_5573448.html "Review: Chigger Foot Boys"], ''HuffPost'', 10 July 2014.</ref> ==Awards== Cumper has won awards for her radio drama, encompassing original works as well as adaptations of the work of other writers, including [[Andrea Levy]], [[Alice Walker]], [[Zora Neale Hurston]] and [[Toni Morrison]].<ref name=govt2013 /> She was runner-up in the inaugural BBC Screenplay First Award.<ref>Gavin Collinson, [http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/writersroom/entries/7e7dd6e4-aba0-4f21-8e71-4de5ff24af00 "BBC Films and BBC Writersroom Announce the Winner of the Inaugural ‘BBC Screenplay First Award’"], Writers Room, BBC, 27 June 2016.</ref>
She is a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of the Arts]] and in 2013 was awarded an MBE for services to Black British Theatre.<ref>[http://africanvoiceonline.co.uk/patricia-cumper-mbe-two-others-reappointed-trustees-british-museum/ "Patricia Cumper MBE, and two others reappointed trustees of the British Museum"], ''African Voice'', 25 April 2017.</ref>
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cumper, Patricia}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Girton College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Trustees of the British Museum]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:British theatre directors]] [[Category:Jamaican women]] [[Category:Black British writers]] [[Category:Jamaican people of English descent]] [[Category:Jamaican emigrants to the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
'''Pavel Dmitriyevich Korin''' ({{lang-ru|Павел Дмитриевич Корин}}; {{OldStyleDate|8 July|1892|25 June}} - 22 November 1967) was a [[Russia]]n painter and art [[art conservation and restoration|restorer]]. He is famous for his preparational work for the unimplemented painting ''Farewell to Rus''.
==Life and career== Pavel Korin was born in the village of [[Palekh]] (now in [[Ivanovo Oblast]]) to a family of a professional [[icon]]-painter Dmitry Nikolayevich Korin. In 1897, when Pavel was only five years old, his father died. In 1903-1907, he studied at the ''School for Icon Painting'' at Palekh getting a formal certificate as a professional icon-painter. In 1908, he moved to [[Moscow]] and until 1911 worked there at the icon shop of the [[Donskoy Monastery|Don Monastery]].
In 1911, he worked as an apprentice to [[Mikhail Nesterov]] on [[fresco]]es of [[The Intercession]] Church at the [[Marfo-Mariinsky Convent|Convent of Martha and Mary]] (''Marfo-Mariinsky'') on Bolshaya Ordynka Street in [[Moscow]]. Nesterov insisted that Korin gain a formal education in easel painting and arranged his admission to the [[Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture]] in 1912. Pavel graduated from that school in 1916, having been a student of [[Konstantin Korovin]] and [[Leonid Pasternak]].
In 1916, he worked on frescoes for the mausoleum of [[Grand Duchess Elizabeth Fyodorovna]] at [[The Intercession]] Church at the Convent of Martha and Mary. In accordance with the wishes of the Grand Duchess, he traveled to [[Yaroslavl]] and [[Rostov]] to study traditional frescoes of antique Russian churches. [[File:Korin konen.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Portrait of sculptor [[Sergey Konenkov]], 1947]]
In February 1917, he started to work in his attic studio on [[Arbat Street]] in [[Moscow]] and worked there until 1934.
In 1918-1919, he taught at the ''2nd State Art Studios'' (2-ые ГСХМ). In 1919-1920 he worked at the ''Anatomic theatre'' of [[Moscow State University]], as he thought that, as a painter, he needed deeper knowledge of the human anatomy. In the evenings he copied paintings and sculptures of the [[Pushkin Museum|Museum of Fine Arts]].
In 1923, he traveled over Northern Russia, visiting [[Vologda]], [[Staraya Ladoga]], [[Ferapontov Monastery]], and [[Veliky Novgorod|Novgorod]]. In 1926-1931, he worked as an instructor of painting classes for beginners at the Museum of Fine Arts.
In 1926, the Convent of Martha and Mary was closed by the Soviets and all the art there was to be destroyed. Pavel and his brother Alexander managed to smuggle out and save the [[iconostasis]] and some of the frescoes. On March 7 of that year he married Praskovya Tikhonovna Petrova, a disciple of the Convent of Martha and Mary.
In 1927, Korin's [[aquarelle]] ''Artist's studio'' and his oil landscape ''My Motherland'' were bought by the [[Tretyakov gallery]], showing recognition from the Soviets.
In 1931, Korin's studio was visited by [[Maxim Gorky]], who supported Korin since. In 1932, Korin followed Gorky to [[Sorrento]], painted Gorky's portrait, and visited [[Italy]] and [[Germany]].
In 1931, Korin started to work as the Head of the [[art conservation and restoration|Restoration]] Shop of [[Pushkin Museum|Museum of the Foreign Art]] (former Museum of Fine Arts later Pushkin Museum). He held this position for until 1959. After this he held the position of the Director of the ''State Central Art Restoration Works'' (ГЦРХМ) until his death. As one of the most senior Russian restorers of the time he contributed enormously to the saving and restoration of famous paintings.
In 1933, Korin moved to the studio on Malaya Pirogovka Street in [[Moscow]] where he worked until his death. Now the building is Korin's museum.
In the 1940s, he painted many portraits of members of the Soviet [[intelligentsia]] (including [[Leonid Leonidov]], [[Mikhail Nesterov]], [[Aleksey Nikolayevich Tolstoy|Alexey Tolstoy]], [[Kachalov]] and Nadezhda Peshkova (Gorky's daughter in law)). He painted the fresco ''Match to the Future'' for the ''Palace of Soviets'' in the [[Moscow Kremlin]] and a [[Triptych]] devoted to [[Alexander Nevsky]]. [[File:Korin russia walking away.jpg|thumb|350px|right|''Farewell to Rus'', preparational drawing showing the composition, 1935-1959]]
In the 1950s, Korin worked on mosaics for the [[Moscow Metro]]. His mosaics decorate the stations [[Komsomolskaya-Koltsevaya]], [[Arbatskaya (Arbatsko-Pokrovskaya Line)]] and [[Novoslobodskaya]], and also the Main Hall (Актовый Зал) of [[Moscow State University]]. He also won an impressive list of Soviet awards in the 1950s and 1960s: *[[Stalin Prize]] - 1954 for mosaics for the station Komsomolskaya-Koltsevaya, *[[Lenin Prize]] - 1963 for portraits of [[Martiros Saryan]], group portrait of cartoonists [[Kukryniksy]], Italian painter [[Renato Guttuso]] *Member of [[Imperial Academy of Arts|Academy of Arts of Soviet Union]] - since 1958 *Gold medal on [[World's Fair]] at [[Brussels]] - 1958 for the portrait of Martiros Saryan, *[[People's Artist of the Russian SFSR]] 1958 *[[People's Artist of the USSR]] - 1962 () *[[Order of Lenin]] - 1967
Pavel Korin died in Moscow on 22 November 1967 and was buried in the [[Novodevichy Cemetery]]. [[File:Korins studio.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Photo of Korin's studio showing the canvas for the ''Farewell to Rus'' drawing, 1960s]]
==''Farewell to Rus''== The biography of Korin shows an accomplished Soviet painter and a prominent art figure, but the job he had considered the main work of his life was left unfinished. During his student years Korin was impressed by the life of [[Alexander Ivanov (painter)|Alexander Ivanov]], who spent most of his adult life in creating a single painting ''The Appearance of Christ before the People'' (1835–1857). Pavel decided that he should live by Ivanov's example and devote his whole life to a single large painting. He began by preparing a very accurate, life sized copy of Ivanov's masterpiece (1920–1925). The initial name for this painting was ''Bless the Lord, oh my soul'' (''Благослови, душе моя, Господа'').
In 1925 Korin witnessed the intercession of [[Patriarch of Moscow|Patriarch]] [[Tikhon of Moscow]] in the [[Cathedral of the Dormition]] of [[Moscow Kremlin]]. All people of importance in the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], usually suppressed by the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]]s, were present. After the event Pavel decided that his magnum opus would be named ''[[Requiem]]'', or ''Requiem for Russia'', and would depict the intercession of Patriarch Tikhon and show the Russia that was lost after the [[October Revolution]]. [[File:Korin Beggar.jpg|thumb|300px|right|''Beggar'', Etude for ''Farewell to Rus'', 1933]]
Korin feverishly painted people present at the burial service for Tikhon, often the last survivors of families of Russian nobility, or dissident priests, soon to be destroyed. Rumors about the dangerous painting soon became a matter of [[NKVD]] interest. In 1931 Maxim Gorky advised Korin that the name ''Requiem for Russia'' was too strong to be accepted and recommended a change to ''Русь Уходящая'' - literally ''[[Russia|Rus]] that is going away'', but usually translated as ''Farewell to Rus''. Gorky believed that the painting showing the last parade of the Orthodox Church, depicting the tragedy and at the same time the misery of those people who would will disappear into irrelevancy, would be accepted and even well received by the Government. Korin agreed with the new name of the painting.
For forty years Korin worked on the painting. He produced dozens of large (more than life size), detailed paintings that he preferred to call [[etude]]s for the ''Farewell to Rus'' masterpiece; he worked on composition. He ordered a huge canvas, designed a special stretcher for it, and spent years coating the canvas with multiple layers of the special underlays. Korin was combining the ancient methods of the icon paintings with the science of [[art restoration]]s and claimed the painting prepared by his methods should survive hundreds, possibly thousands of years without the need for restoration.
In his lifetime, he had not put a single brushstroke on the canvas - forty-two years of preparational work was not enough for Pavel Korin. Though some might consider it an extreme case of [[procrastination]], the huge canvas became a popular art exhibit in the Korin Museum. Many consider it as an art masterpiece in its own right, similar to the ''Black Square'' of [[Kazimir Malevich]].
==External links== *[http://korin.webzone.ru Site devoted to Korin] {{ru icon}} *[http://www.c-cafe.ru/days/bio/1/059.php Biography of Korin] {{ru icon}} *N. A Ionina ''100 great paintings'', {{ISBN|5-7838-0579-3}} {{ru icon}} *[http://artiststudiomuseum.org/studio-museums/house-museum-pavel-korin/ House Museum of Pavel Korin] {{Authority control}}
