revision.text:
{{Infobox artefact | image = | image_caption = Plastered human skull from Jericho on display in the British Museum | material = Plaster and bone | size = 20.3 cm high | writing = | created = 7000–6000 BC | discovered = | location = [[British Museum]], [[London]] | id = | registration = ME 127414 }} '''Plastered human skulls''' are reconstructed human skulls that were made in the ancient [[Levant]] between 7000 and 6000 BC in the [[Pre-Pottery Neolithic B]] period. They represent some of the oldest forms of art in the [[Middle East]] and demonstrate that the prehistoric population took great care in burying their [[ancestors]] below their homes. The skulls denote some of the earliest sculptural examples of [[portrait]]ure in the [[history of art]].
==Discovery== One skull was accidentally unearthed in the 1930s by the archaeologist [[John Garstang]] at [[Jericho]] in the [[West Bank]]. A number of plastered skulls from Jericho were discovered by the British archaeologist [[Kathleen Kenyon]] in the 1950s and can now be found in the collections of the [[British Museum]], the [[Ashmolean Museum]], the [[Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, University of Cambridge|Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]], the [[Royal Ontario Museum]], the [[Nicholson Museum]] in Sydney and the [[Jordan Archaeological Museum]].<ref>ROM Collection [http://images.rom.on.ca/public/index.php?function=image&action=simpledetail&image_name=ROM2004_1044_7 ROM Images. "Plastered Human Skull."]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ashmolean.org/collections/highlights/?type=highlights&id=33&department=1|title=TREASURES {{!}} Ashmolean Museum|website=www.ashmolean.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://maa.cam.ac.uk/maa-highlights/middleeast/israel_palestine/388/|title=MAA - Features|website=maa.cam.ac.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>
Other sites where plastered skulls were excavated include [[Ain Ghazal]] and [[Amman]], [[Jordan]], and [[Tell Ramad]], [[Syria]].<ref name=bm>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/me/p/plastered_skull.aspx The British Museum. "Plastered Skull."]</ref> Most of the plastered skulls were from adult males, but some belonged to women and children.
==Archaeological significance== The plastered skulls represent some of the earliest forms of burial practices in the southern [[Levant]]. During the [[Neolithic]] period, the deceased were often buried under the floors of their homes.<ref name=bm/> Sometimes the skull was removed, and its cavities filled with plaster and painted. In order to create more lifelike faces, [[Seashell|shells]] were inset for eyes, and paint was used to represent facial features, hair, and [[moustaches]].<ref name=bm/><ref>[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/the-neolithic-revolution.html German, Senta. "The Neolithic Revolution."]</ref> Some scholars believe that this burial practice represents an early form of [[ancestor worship]], where the plastered skulls were used to commemorate and respect family ancestors.<ref name=bm/> Other experts argue that the plastered skulls could be linked to the practice of head hunting, and used as trophies. Plastered skulls provide evidence about the earliest arts and [[religious]] practices in the [[ancient Near East]].
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Human skull from Beisamoun.JPG|Skull from [[Beisamoun]] on exhibition at the Moshe Stekelis Museum of Prehistory </gallery>
==Further reading== *D. Collon, Ancient Near Eastern art (London, The British Museum Press, 1995) *J.N. Tubb, Canaanites (London, The British Museum Press, 1998) *German, Senta. “[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/the-neolithic-revolution.html The Neolithic Revolution].” Khana Academy. *Strouhal, E. [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/paleo_0153-9345_1973_num_1_2_4169 ''Five Plastered Skulls from Pre-Pottery Neolithic B Jericho: Anthropological Study''] Paléorient 1:1-2 (1973): 231-247. *{{cite book|last=Mazar|first=Amihai|title=Archaeology of the land of the Bible|year=1990|publisher=Doubleday|location=New York|isbn=038523970X|edition=1st}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Neolithic]] [[Category:Archaeology of the Near East]] [[Category:Collections of the Royal Ontario Museum]] [[Category:Middle Eastern objects in the British Museum]] [[Category:Ancient Jericho]] [[Category:Neolithic settlements]] [[Category:Prehistoric art]] [[Category:Collection of the Ashmolean Museum]]

{{Infobox book | name = Primary Colors: A Novel of Politics | image = Primary colors book cover.JPG |caption = | author = "Anonymous"
later revealed as [[Joe Klein]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United States]] | language = [[English language|English]] | genre = [[Political novel]] | publisher = [[Random House]] | release_date = January 16, 1996 | media_type = [[Hardcover]] and [[Paperback]] | pages = 366 (hc) | isbn = 0-679-44859-4 | isbn_note = (hc) | dewey= 813/.54 20 | congress= PS3550.A1 P75 1996 | oclc= 33166616 | preceded_by = | followed_by =The Running Mate }} '''''Primary Colors: A Novel of Politics''''' is a ''[[roman à clef]]'', a work of fiction that actually describes real life characters and events – namely, [[Bill Clinton]]'s first [[Bill Clinton presidential campaign, 1992|presidential campaign]] in [[U.S. presidential election, 1992|1992]]. It has been compared to two other novels about American politics: [[Robert Penn Warren]]'s ''[[All the King's Men]]'' (1946) and ''[[O: A Presidential Novel]]'' (2011). The book was originally published by an anonymous author, who was later found to be columnist [[Joe Klein (journalist)|Joe Klein]]. Klein completed a sequel of sorts, ''The Running Mate'' in 2000, focusing on the ''Primary Colors'' character of Charlie Martin. ==Unmasking of "Anonymous"== An early reviewer opined that the author wished to remain unknown because "Anonymity makes truthfulness much easier". Later commentators called the publishing of the book under an anonymous identity an effective marketing strategy that produced more publicity for the book, and thus more sales, without calling into question the author's actual inside knowledge. Several people, including former Clinton speechwriter David Kusnet, believed the style of writing had similarities to that of Klein. This was also supported by a quantitative [[stylometry|stylometric]] analysis of the book by [[Vassar College|Vassar]] professor [[Donald Foster (professor)|Donald Foster]].[http://www.salon.com/2000/11/02/foster_5/ ''Author Unknown'' by Gavin McNett Salon November 2, 2000] Klein initially denied writing the book and publicly condemned Foster. Klein denied authorship again in ''[[Newsweek]]'', speculating that another writer wrote it. ''[[Washington Post]]'' Style editor David von Drehle, in an interview, asked Klein if he was willing to stake his journalistic credibility on his denial, to which Klein agreed. On July 17, 1996, after ''The Washington Post'' published the results of a handwriting analysis of notes made on an early manuscript of the book, Klein finally admitted that he was "Anonymous". ==Plot summary== The book begins as an idealistic former congressional worker, Henry Burton, joins the presidential campaign of Southern governor Jack Stanton, a thinly disguised stand-in for [[Bill Clinton]]. The plot then follows the primary election calendar beginning in New Hampshire where Stanton's affair with Cashmere, his wife's hairdresser, and his participation in a Vietnam War era protest come to light and threaten to derail his presidential prospects. In Florida, Stanton revives his campaign by disingenuously portraying his Democratic opponent as insufficiently pro-Israel and as a weak supporter of Social Security. Burton becomes increasingly disillusioned with Stanton, who is a policy wonk who talks too long, eats too much and is overly flirtatious toward women. Stanton is also revealed to be insincere in his beliefs, saying whatever will help him to win. Matters finally come to a head, and Burton is forced to choose between idealism and realism. ==Reviews== ''The New York Daily News'' described the book as a farce and praised it as funny, truthful, and as containing "uncannily accurate" portraits of its thinly disguised characters. ==Fictional characters and believed real-life inspirations== * '''Jack Stanton''', southern governor – ([[Bill Clinton]]) * '''Susan Stanton''', his wife – ([[Hillary Clinton]]) * '''Henry Burton''', campaign manager – ([[George Stephanopoulos]]) * '''Richard Jemmons''', campaign strategist – ([[James Carville]]) * '''Daisy Green''', campaign media adviser – ([[Mandy Grunwald]] and/or [[Dee Dee Myers]]) * '''Howard Ferguson, III''', campaign chief – ([[Harold M. Ickes|Harold Ickes, Jr.]]) * '''Orlando Ozio''', New York governor – ([[Mario Cuomo]]) * '''Jimmy Ozio''', his son – ([[Andrew Cuomo]]) * '''Charlie Martin''', U.S. senator – ([[Bob Kerrey]]) * '''Lawrence Harris''', former senator – ([[Paul Tsongas]]) * '''Bart Nilson''', U.S. senator – [[Tom Harkin]] * '''Freddy Picker''', former Florida Governor – ([[Jerry Brown]]) / ([[Reubin Askew]]) / ([[Harold Hughes]]) / ([[Ross Perot]]) * '''Richmond Rucker''', NYC Mayor – ([[David Dinkins]]) * '''Luther Charles''', minister – ([[Jesse Jackson]]) * '''Cashmere McLeod''', suspected lover of Jack Stanton – ([[Gennifer Flowers]]) * '''Lucille Kauffman''', adviser to Susan Stanton – ([[Susan Thomases]]) * '''Libby Holden''' (campaign chief of staff) – ([[Betsey Wright]]/ [[Vince Foster]]) ==Related film== * ''[[The War Room]]'', a documentary of Clinton's 1992 campaign. ==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[Politics in fiction]] * [[Primary Colors (film)|''Primary Colors'' (film)]] ==References== {{Reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs = {{cite news|url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C07E3DF1E39F93AA25752C0A960958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all|title=Books of the Times; A Roman a Clef to Recent Politics|author=Michiko Kakutani|date=January 19, 1996|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/time/9601/29/primary.colors/index.shtml|title=Author! Author!|author= Walter Shapiro|date=January 29, 1996|publisher=Time/CNN|work=CNN All Politics|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/01/us/the-author-could-not-be-reached-for-comment.html?scp=1&sq=the%20author%20could%20not%20be%20reached%20&st=cse|title=The Author Could Not Be Reached for Comment|author=Todd S. Burdum|date=February 1, 1996|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2242/is_n1563_v268/ai_18395598/|title=Primary Colors: A Nover of Politics|author=Richard K. Thompson|work=Contemporary Review|date=April 1996|accessdate=January 25, 2011}} {{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70E1FF93F5C0C728EDDA00894DF494D81|title=Bill Clinton's Garbage Man|author=Michael Lewis|date=September 21, 1997|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0005/02/cf.00.html|series=CNN transcripts|title='Primary Colors' Author Joe Klein Talks About Political Truth and Fiction|work=Crossfire|publisher=CNN|date=May 2, 2000|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/us/it-s-andrew-cuomo-s-turn-at-bat-and-some-see-makings-of-slugger.html|title=It's Andrew Cuomo's Turn at Bat|author=Lizette Alvarex|date=January 4, 1998|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2000/books/news/12/06/foster.anonymous/|author=Jamie Allen|work=CNN|title=Don Foster enlightens readers with 'Author Unknown'|date=December 6, 2000|accessdate=January 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609190548/http://archives.cnn.com/2000/books/news/12/06/foster.anonymous/|archivedate=June 9, 2009|df=}} {{cite web|url=http://www.nwitimes.com/entertainment/columnists/offbeat/article_0911dc3c-794d-5215-947a-08ce83df7803.html|title=Former Clinton female press rep. Dee Dee Myers in Chicago with new memoir|author=Philip Potempa|work=nwi.com|date=March 6, 2008|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ADSB&s_site=azstarnet&f_site=azstarnet&f_sitename=Arizona+Daily+Star%2C+The+%28AZ%29&p_multi=ADSB&p_theme=gannett&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EACE6415108B806&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Gray gobbledygook|date=March 23, 1998|work=Arizona Daily Star}} {{cite news|url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/departments/generalfiction/story/0,,2239268,00.html |work=The Guardian |location=London |title=The great unknown |first=John |last=Mullan |date=January 12, 2008 |accessdate=May 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080113145536/http://books.guardian.co.uk/departments/generalfiction/story/0%2C%2C2239268%2C00.html |archivedate=January 13, 2008 |df= }} {{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/heres-to-you-mr-president-1319374.html|title=Here's to you Mr President |author=Rupert Cornwell|date=February 16, 1996|work=The Independent|location=London|accessdate=January 22, 2011}} {{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/16218877.html?dids=16218877:16218877&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Mar+17%2C+1996&author=ANONYME&pub=Boston+Globe+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Political+intrigue+served+with+literary+success&pqatl=google|title=Political intrigue served with literary success|work=Boston Globe|date=March 17, 1996}} {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/00/04/23/reviews/000423.23tarloft.html|title=Loyalty, Decency, Compassion, Love - There's none of that stuff in the Washington of Joe Klein's new novel|author=Erik Tarloff|date=April 23, 2000|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 21, 2011}} {{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9901E6DB1F39F93BA25754C0A960958260|title= Columnist's Mea Culpa: I'm Anonymous|author=Doreen Carvajal|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 18, 1996|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} {{cite web|url= http://www.weeklystandard.com/article/8414|title=The Media's True Colors |author=Tod Lindberg |work=[[The Weekly Standard]] |date=July 29, 1996 }} {{cite news|title=Politics Makes Funny Bedfellows|author=Michael Aronson|work=New York Daily News|date=January 22, 1996}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,282380,00.html|title=Primary Colors Reviewed|author=Lisa Schwarzbaum|date=March 27, 1998|work=EW.com|accessdate=January 22, 2011}} {{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1996/01/22/1996-01-22_roman_a_clinton__of__primary.html|title=Roman A Clinton Of 'Primary' Interest In D.C.; Who Knew The White House Well Enough To Paint Its 'Colors' Vividly In A Juicy New Novel?|author=Sherryl Connelly with Karen Ball|date=January 22, 1996|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=January 20, 2011}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wrote-anonymous-president-obamas-2012-presidential-campaign/story?id=12585042&page=2|title=Who Wrote 'O'? New Anonymous Novel Pictures Barack Obama's 2012 Presidential Campaign|date=January 11, 2011|author=Eliza Larson|work=ABC News|accessdate=January 20, 2011}} }} ==External links== * [http://www.randomhouse.com/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780307559234&view=excerpt Random House - Book website and excerpt] {{DEFAULTSORT:Primary Colors (Novel)}} [[Category:1992 in fiction]] [[Category:1996 American novels]] [[Category:American novels adapted into films]] [[Category:American political novels]] [[Category:American satirical novels]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] [[Category:Novels about elections]] [[Category:Random House books]] [[Category:Roman à clef novels]] [[Category:Works published anonymously]]

The '''Sarcophagus of Stilicho''' is a marble [[Early Christian art|Early Christian]] [[sarcophagus]] used since before the 10th-century as the base for the pulpit of the church of [[Sant'Ambrogio, Milan|San Ambrogio]] in Milan, Italy. It appears to have been made some decades prior to the death of Stilicho, and thus likely not associated with the Roman General.
==Description== The sarcophagus was carved from Marble from quarries near [[Como]], but appears to date stylistically from circa 390 and the reign of [[Theodosius the Great]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1kSpN3Kfgc0C Early Christian and Byzantine Art], by John Beckwith, Richard Krautheimer, Slobodan Ćurčić; page 46.</ref> The panels depict both New and Old Testament scenes including:<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=3-NhdelLo1oC DK Eyewitness Guide to Milan], page 86.</ref> *''Christ giving law to St Peter'' *''Christ among the Apostles'' *''Sacrifice of Isaac''
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Sarcofago detto di stilicone, IV secolo, gesù tra gli apostoli 03.jpg|Jesus among the Apostles File:Sarcofago detto di stilicone, IV secolo, 05.jpg|side panel File:Sarcofago detto di stilicone, IV secolo, 08.jpg|Triumph with [[quadriga]] File:Sarcofago detto di stilicone, IV secolo, gesù tra gli apostoli 01.jpg </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sarcophagus of Stilicho}} [[Category:Ancient Roman sarcophagi|Stilicho]] [[Category:Jesus in art]] [[Category:Christian iconography]] [[Category:4th-century Roman sculptures]] [[Category:Early Christian art]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Sava Sekulić
Сава Секулић | image = Sekulić Sava - portret umetnika.jpg | imagesize = | alt = Sava Sekulić, Serbian outsider and naïve painter | caption = Sava Sekulić | birth_name = Sava Sekulić | birth_date = {{Birth date|1902|02|17}} | birth_place = Bilišane ([[Obrovac, Croatia|Obrovac]])
{{flagcountry|Croatia}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1989|01|26|1902|02|17}} | death_place = [[Belgrade]]
{{flagcountry|Yugoslavia}} | nationality = [[Serbs|Serb]] | field = [[Painter]] | movement = [[Outsider art]], [[Naïve art]] | website = [http://www.marginalart.rs/], [http://www.mnmu.rs/] }} '''Sava Sekulić''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Сава Секулић}}; Bilišane, [[Obrovac, Croatia|Obrovac]], February 17, 1902 – [[Belgrade]], January 26, 1989) was a [[Serbia]]n [[Naive art|Naïve]] and [[Outsider art|Outsider]] [[painter]]. ==Biography== He was born in Bilišani in [[Dalmatinska Zagora]] near [[Obrovac, Croatia|Obrovac]], as a [[Serb]] in [[Croatia]] at the [[Adriatic Sea]] coast, in 1902. His mother remarried when his father died when he was 10 years old.Sava Sekulić was raised by his uncle and his aunt. He never attended any schools. His father taught him to read and write. Also, Sava used to quote his father's last words: ''Learn by yourself, draw and write with a stone in your hand''. During [[World War I]], he was harmed and lost one eye when he was 15 years old. He started writing poems when he was 22 and painting in 1932, but he did not dedicate himself to painture exclusively. In 1943, during the [[World War II]] he began to work as a [[Construction worker|builder]]. Parallel to writing poems, after his retirement in 1962, Sava began to do [[painting]] in order to define his [[poetry]] more precisely. Sekulić belongs to the group of the so-called [[outsider art]]ists, lonely, bizarre, asocial people who create new forms of beauty. His unusual associativity and ability for materialization of his intellectual energy as a complete [[self-taught]] was intuitively and instinctively released. He died in Belgrade, Serbia, in 1989.М. Бошковић; М.Маширевић, Самоуки ликовни уметници у Србији, Торино, 1977; 74, 78Н. Крстић, Наивна уметност Србије, [https://www.sanu.ac.rs/english/ SANU], [http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Jagodina, 2003; p. 100 == Artistic style == Sekulić is a painter of the universal, the timeless and the limitless. For him everything is generalized, from the individual he aspires to the universal, and is very successful. Therefore, his works are the highest achievements of [[Outsider art|L'art brut]], not only in the country, but worldwide. [[Allegories]] and [[metaphors]] are present in nearly all his works. With his visions he reduced a unique pictorial definition, minimized the subject matter to a metaphor. Most numerous are his compositions with [[human]] [[Shape|figures]], [[portraits]] and scenes with historical and [[mythological|beings]]. While painting historical personalities, he portrayed the [[wikt:victim|victims]] as [[hero]]es, and the members of his family as [[mythological]] beings. However, the most complex is the figure of a woman. In many works there are [[philosophical]] stories and moralizing lessons. Figures are simplified, flat and highly stylised. In the background of every painting is an original story derived from numerous popular [[legend]]s and beliefs – [[pagan]], [[Christian]], [[mythological]], [[historical]] or [[contemporary]]. The [[myths]] with the pronounced respect for animals – primordial parents and beliefs on summing up people and animals are presented in his paintings by duplication and compaction of human and animal figure (fish, bird, horse, cow, snake, octopus, deer, bull, he-goat...), multiplication of heads and limbs. The artist prefigured the symbiosis of anthropomorphic and zoomorphic figures, where all the [[alchemy]] of his pictorial expression is clearly visible. It is paradoxical that the artist’s very style counteracts the narrative aspect of the painting and concentrates totally on the pictorial value with the strength on an unconscious [[neo-primitive]]. His palette is restricted. He often paints surfaces with different applications of transparent colours, one over the other, without waiting for the earlier layer to dry, which leads to mixing and assimilation of colours. One colour is often predominant in each painting, which sometimes creates a [[monochrome]] [[wikt:impression|impression]]. He sometimes only partly paints the background of certain paintings, thus leaving whole surfaces unpainted. This additionally eliminated any [[illusion]] of spatial depth. Sekulić’s paintings are pervaded with a number of inventive characteristics, the symbiosis of the real and the surreal, with the character of almost pure automatism. The superiority of the artist’s senses overgrows the perception of a beholder. An ordinary observer is not capable of noticing and understanding sensitive structure of purely [[pictorial]] [[phenomena]]; his paintings are firstly accepted as a kind of visual intrigue and are later intellectually experienced. Finally, Sava Sekulić is one of the greatest Serbian [[Outsider art|outsider]] and [[Naive art|naïve]] painters and a world classic also.N. Krstić, Outsider Art in Serbia, monograph, MNMA, Јагодина, 2014, pp. 108-113 ==Exhibitions and awards== The best of his paintings are in the collections of [http://www.mnmu.rs Museum of Naïve and Marginal Art (MNMA)], [[Jagodina]], [[Serbia]] and in Galerie Charlotte Zander, Bönningheim, Germany. He participated in independent and group shows in the country: [[Belgrade]], [[Zagreb]], [[Aranđelovac]], [[Jagodina]], as well as abroad in significant international exhibitions in:[[Munich]], [[Paris]], [[Cologne]], etc.[http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Jagodina He received many prominent international awards. For his works he was also awarded posthumously at the ''Fifth World Triennial of Naïve and Marginal Art IN SITA'' in [[Bratislava]], 2000, etc.). == Gallery == Sekulić Sava, Stari Sloven.jpg|''Ancient Sloven'', 1975,
oil on cardboard, 110x76cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] Sekulić Sava, Jelengrad.jpg|''Jelengrad (Deer-City'', 1948),
oil on cardboard, 74x97cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] Sekulić Sava, Priroda hoda preko nebeskog svoda.jpg|''Nature Walks over the Sky'', 1974,
oil on cardboard, 102x70cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] Sekulić Sava, Klica života.jpg|''The Germ of Life'', 1974,
oil on cardboard, 72x102cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] Sekulić Sava, Kad svak uzme svoje.jpg|''When everyone took his'', 1965,
combined technique on cardboard, 92x73cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] Sekulić Sava, Jabučilo i Momčilo.jpg|''Jabučilo and Momčilo'', 1974,
oil on cardboard, 100x70cm
[http://www.mnma.rs MNMA]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Jagodina]] ==References== {{reflist}} == Literature == * М. Бошковић; М.Маширевић, Самоуки ликовни уметници у Србији, Торино, 1977; 74, 78 * Н. Крстић, Наивна уметност Србије, [https://www.sanu.ac.rs/english/ SANU], [http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Jagodina, 2003; p. 100 * Н. Крстић, Наивна и маргинална уметност Србије, [http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Jagodina, 2007 * N. Krstić, Outsiders, catalogue, [http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Jagodina, 2013 * N. Krstić, Outsider Art in Serbia, [http://www.mnmu.rs MNMA], Јагодина, 2014; pp. 120–129 ==External links== {{portal|Biography}} * [http://www.marginalart.rs/ Sava Sekulić, Marginal Art in Serbia, Jagodina, Serbia] * [http://www.mnmu.rs/ Sava Sekulić, Museum of Naïve and Marginal Art, Jagodina, Serbia] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sekulic, Sava}} [[Category:Outsider artists]] [[Category:Naïve art]] [[Category:Naïve painters]] [[Category:Yugoslav painters]] [[Category:20th-century Serbian painters]] [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{About||the use of the term "scene" in motion picture|Scene (film)|other uses|Scene (disambiguation)}} In [[drama]], a '''scene''' is a unit of action, often a subdivision of an [[Act (drama)|act]].
==French scene== A "French scene" is a scene in which the beginning and end are marked by a change in the presence of characters onstage, rather than by the lights going up or down or the set being changed.<ref name="George">George, Kathleen (1994) ''Playwriting: The First Workshop'', Focal Press, {{ISBN|978-0-240-80190-2}}, p. 154</ref>
==Obligatory scene== From the French ''scène à faire'', an obligatory scene is a scene (usually highly charged with emotion) which is anticipated by the audience and provided by an obliging playwright. An example is ''[[Hamlet]]'' 3.4, when Hamlet confronts his mother.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cuddon|first=J. A.|authorlink=J. A. Cuddon|editor=C. E. Preston|title=The Penguin Dictionary Literary Terms and Literary Terminology|year=1998|publisher=Penguin|location=London|isbn=9780140513639|page=606|chapter=obligatory scene}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Scene and sequel]] * [[Plot (narrative)]] * [[Fiction]] * [[Theatrical scenery]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Scene (Drama)}} [[Category:Plot (narrative)]] [[Category:Narratology]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Seven''''' is a documentary play, first performed in 2008, written by seven women playwrights based on interviews with seven women around the world who have fought for the rights and well-being of women and girls.<ref name=dramatists>{{cite web|title=Seven|url=http://www.dramatists.com/cgi-bin/db/single.asp?key=4059|publisher=Dramatists Play Service|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref>
==The women== The women whose stories form the basis of ''Seven'' are all involved in the [[Vital Voices Global Partnership]]. They are:<ref name=dramatists /> * [[Hafsat Abiola]], Nigeria, who founded the Kudirat Initiative for Democracy and works to improve relations between Chinese and African women; winner of 2016 [[Global Leadership Award]] for Leadership in Public Life<ref name="past">{{cite web|title=Past Global Leadership Awards|url=http://www.vitalvoices.org/global-initiatives/past-global-leadership-awards|publisher=Vital Voices Global Partnership|accessdate=23 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027171231/http://www.vitalvoices.org/global-initiatives/past-global-leadership-awards|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=}}</ref> *[[Farida Azizi]], Afghanistan, campaigner for women's rights and peace in her country<ref name="past" /> *[[Annabella De Leon]], Guatemala, congresswoman and campaigner against corruption and for the rights of the poor; winner of 2003 [[Global Leadership Award]] for Political Participation *[[Mukhtar Mai]], Pakistan, survivor of a gang rape and campaigner for women's education; winner of 2006 Global Leadership Awards Fern Holland Award<ref name="past" /> *[[Inez McCormack]], Northern Ireland, former president of the [[Irish Congress of Trade Unions]]; winner of 2002 Global Leadership Award for Political Participation<ref name="past" /> *[[Marina Pisklakova-Parker]], Russia, founder of first Russian hot-line for victimes of domestic violence; winner of 2004 Global Leadership Award for Human Rights<ref name="past" /> *[[Mu Sochua]], Cambodia, former Minister of Women's Affairs and campaigner against sex-trafficking; winner of 2005 Global Leadership Award for Human Rights<ref name="past" />
==The playwrights== Seven women collaborated to write the play:<ref name=dramatists /> *[[Anna Deavere Smith]] *[[Ruth Margraff]] *[[Gail Kriegel]] *[[Paula Cizmar]] *[[Susan Yankowitz]] *[[Carol K. Mack]] *[[Catherine Filloux]]
==Development of the play== Each playwright worked with one of the women whose stories make up the play over a series of interviews in 2006-2007, and wrote a dramatic monologue based on these. The writers met in February 2007 to read the monologues together, and then worked them into a unified script during a Residency Fellowship retreat at [[Bard College]]. The first draft was read in July 2007.<ref name=story>{{cite web|title=The Story of Seven|url=https://seventheplay.com/the-story-of-seven/|website=Seven - a documentary play|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref>
The play was first performed on 21 January 2008 at the [[92nd Street Y]] in [[New York City|New York]], directed by [[Evan Yionoulis]]. Since then it has been translated into 20 languages and performed in 32 countries, {{as of|lc=yes|May 2016}}.<ref name=story /><ref name=about>{{cite web|title=About Seven|url=https://seventheplay.com/about-seven/|website=Seven - a documentary play|accessdate=23 May 2016}}</ref>
Some productions have involved well-known professional actors, as when [[Meryl Streep]] read the part of Inez McCormack at the [[Hudson Theatre]] on New York's Broadway.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Mary|title=Inez McCormack obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2013/feb/01/inez-mccormack|accessdate=23 May 2016|work=The Guardian|date=1 February 2013}}</ref><ref name="mcgarrigle">{{cite news|last1=McGarrigle|first1=Heather|title=Why Meryl Streep needs to get an Northern Ireland accent|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/why-meryl-streep-needs-to-get-an-northern-ireland-accent-28521288.html|accessdate=23 May 2016|work=Belfast Telegraph|date=2 March 2010}}</ref> Other productions have involved amateur groups or public figures, as when a group of senior Belarus government ministers performed it in Minsk in 2015<ref name="minsk">{{cite news|title=Belarus' high-ranking officials take part in documentary play on women's rights|url=http://eng.belta.by/society/view/belarus-high-ranking-officials-take-part-in-documentary-play-on-womens-rights-86699-2015/|accessdate=23 May 2016|work=Belarus News|date=3 November 2015}}</ref> and Washington Supreme Court justice [[Mary Yu]] read the part of Farida Azizi at [[Town Hall Seattle]] in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gruener|first1=Posey|title=For One Night, A Washington Supreme Court Justice Will Step Into An Afghan Woman's Shoes|url=http://kuow.org/post/one-night-washington-supreme-court-justice-will-step-afghan-womans-shoes|publisher=KUOW.org|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=3 March 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|https://seventheplay.com/}}
[[Category:2008 plays]] [[Category:Docudrama plays]] [[Category:Biographical plays]] [[Category:Feminist theatre]]

revision.text:
'''Shabaka''' are [[stained glass]] windows made by national [[Azerbaijan]]i masters, without glue or nails.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Орнамент (шебеке) | url=http://www.azerbaijans.com/content_199_ru.html | publisher= azerbaijans.com | date= | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Шебеке | url=http://www.vokrugsveta.ru/vs/article/5583/ | publisher= Журнал «Вокруг Света» | date= | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>К. М. Мамед-заде. Строительное искусство Азербайджана. — Баку: Элм, 1983.</ref>
Shabaka fill walls and window openings of halls and rooms in the [[Palace of Shaki Khans]]. Geometric patterns of shabaka-windows harmonize with the general composition of the palace’s façade. Stained-glass windows of central halls and side rooms open on the façade. These stained glass windows are the special feature in the palace’s architecture.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Shaki-Paradise in the Caucasus Foothills | url=http://azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/62_folder/62_articles/62_shaki.html | publisher=Azerbaijan International | date= 1998 | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>Л. С. Бретеницкий, Б. В. Веймарн. Искусство Азербайджана IV—XVIII веков. — М.: Искусство, 1976.</ref>
==Gallery== <center> <gallery caption="Shebeke" perrow="5" widths="200px" heights="250px"> Image:Shaki khan palace 1.jpg|Shabaka-windows in interior of the [[Palace of Shaki Khans]] Image:Shekikhanentrance.jpg|Shabaka-windows in facade of the [[Palace of Shaki Khans]]. </gallery> </center>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commonscat|Shebeke}} [[Category:Arts in Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Azerbaijani inventions]] [[Category:Architectural elements]] [[Category:Decorative arts]] [[Category:Glass art]]

revision.text:
'''TV Lab''' (short for Television Laboratory) was a program founded at [[WNET|Thirteen/WNET]] public television station in 1972 by [[David Loxton]] with support from the [[Rockefeller Foundation]] and [[New York State Council on the Arts]]. The program provided artists with advanced video making equipment through an artist-in-residence program. Between 1975 and 1977, the Video Tape Review series was established and broadcast through TV Lab. David Loxton created TV Lab's Independent Documentary Fund in 1977, aiming to provide funding for the creation of independent documentaries. Unable to match funds from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]], the IDF and TV Lab lost support, eventually ending in 1984.<ref name="vanishingvision">{{cite book|last=Day|first=James|title=The Vanishing Vision: The Inside Story of Public Television|year=1995|publisher=Berkeley: University of California Press|location=Berkeley, CA|isbn=9780520086593|page=318}}</ref>
==History== In 1971, the Rockefeller Foundation donated $150,000 for the establishment of TV Lab. At the time, [[Howard Klein (music critic)|Howard Klein]] was Assistant Director at the Rockefeller Foundation and played an instrumental role in the Rockefeller Foundation's decision to donate to TV Lab at Thirteen/WNET, working with [[WGBH-TV|WGBH]]'s Fred Barzyk and artist Nam June Paik, among others. Initially, [[John Jay Iselin]], WNET's President at the time, suggested Robert Kotlowitz for the role of TV Lab director, but artists involved in the project expressed discontent with the proposal. Barzyk then suggested David Loxton for the position of Director, and in 1972 TV Lab began under Loxton's direction with additional grants from the New York State Council on the Arts.<ref name="SturkenKlein">{{cite journal|last=Sturken|first=Marita|title=Howard Klein and the Rockefeller Foundation's funding of the media arts|journal=Afterimage|date=January 1987|volume=14|issue=6}}</ref>
Between 1972 and 1974, TV Lab primarily operated through an artist-in-residence program, supporting artists in the creation of [[video art]]. [[Nam June Paik]], [[Dimitri Devyatkin]], [[Ed Emshwiller]], [[Shirley Clarke]], and [[Douglas Davis (artist)|Douglas Davis]] were among artists who participated in the artist-in-residence program during this initial period.<ref>{{cite journal|last=London|first=Barbara|title=Video: A Selected Chronology, 1963-1983|journal=Art Journal|date=Autumn 1985|volume=45|issue=3|page=254}}</ref> In 1973, [[TVTV (video collective)|TVTV video collective]] came to Loxton seeking support for a guerrilla video project about guru Maharaj-Ji and his followers at the Houston Astrodome.<ref name="vanishingvision" /> This became TV Lab's first video documentary, ''Lord of the Universe'', marking the beginning of TV Lab's venture into non-fiction video.
In 1975, the Video Tape Review (VTR) series hosted by Russell Connor was established as part of TV Lab, airing until 1977.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gever|first=Martha|title=Pressure Points: Video in the Public Sphere|journal=Art Journal|date=Autumn 1985|volume=45|issue=3|page=240}}</ref> VTR was used to introduce viewers to artists at TV Lab and provide some exposure to their work, and in its two years, featured the work of artists and video collectives including Jon Alpert and Keiko Tsuno, TVTV, Broadside TV, and Video Freex. In 1977, David Loxton created the Independent Documentary Fund (IDF) at TV Lab, founded by the [[Ford Foundation]] and [[National Endowment for the Arts]]. The IDF provided funds for independent documentaries such as [[Jack Willis|Jack Willis']] ''[[Paul Jacobs and the Nuclear Gang]]'' and [[Rob Epstein|Robert Epstein's]] ''[[The Times of Harvey Milk]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Weinberg|first=Howard|title=Nam June Paik and TV Lab: License to Create|url=http://media.gfem.org/node/9494|publisher=Grantmakers in Film and Electronic Media|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006045021/http://media.gfem.org/node/9494|archivedate=2013-10-06|df=}}</ref>
In 1984, TV Lab lost funding from the [[Corporation for Public Broadcasting]] when Program Fund Director Lewis Freedman did not renew CPB funds, and TV Lab was unable to match required funds from the National Endowment for the Arts.<ref name="vanishingvision" /><ref name="SturkenKlein" />
==Productions== Between 1972 and 1984, several artists and video collectives produced work at TV Lab.
* [[Nam June Paik]] - ''Global Groove'' (1973), ''A Tribute to John Cage'' (1973), ''Nam June Paik: Edited for Television'' (1975), ''You can't lick stamps in China'' (1978), ''Media Shuttle: Moscow/New York'' (1978) (collaboration with Devyatkin) * [[Ed Emshwiller]] - ''Crossings and Meetings'' (1974), ''Sur Faces'' (1977), ''Dubs'' (1978) * [[Douglas Davis (artist)|Douglas Davis]] - ''Video Against Video'' (1975) * [[Dimitri Devyatkin]] - ''Media Shuttle: Moscow/New York'' (1978) (collaboration with Paik) * [[Bill Viola]] - ''Junkyard Levitation'' (1976), ''The Space Between the Teeth'' (1976), ''Songs of Innocence'' (1976), ''Truth Through Mass Individuation'' (1976), ''The Wheel of Becoming'' (1977), ''The Morning After the Night of Power'' (1977), ''Sweet Light'' (1977), ''The Reflecting Pool'' (1979), ''Moonblood'' (1979), ''Silent Life'' (1979), ''Anthem'' (1983) * [[Joan Jonas]] - ''I Want to Live in the Country (And Other Romances)'' (1976), ''Double Lunar Dogs'' (1984) * [[Gary Hill]] - ''Soundings'' (1979) * [[Skip Blumberg]] - ''Pick Up Your Feet: The Double Dutch Show'' (1981) * [[John Sanborn (media artist) | John Sanborn]] - ''Exchange in Three Parts'' (1977), ''Resolution of the Eye'' (1979), ''Olympic Fragments'' (1980)
more when I get a chance
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Video art]] [[Category:Public television in the United States]] [[Category:American art]]

revision.text:
[[File:The Dinner and Ball in the Teatro San Benedetto Venice, in Honour of the Conti Del Nord, 22nd January 1782.jpg|thumb|[[Francesco Guardi]]. The Dinner and Ball in honour of [[Paul I of Russia|Count]] and [[Maria Feodorovna (Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg)|Countess De Nord]]. Teatro San Benedetto, 22nd January 1782]] [[File:L'italiana in Algeri set design by Francesco Bagnara.jpg|thumb|210 px|Set design by [[Francesco Bagnara]] for the production of ''[[L'italiana in Algeri]]'' at the Teatro San Benedetto in 1826]] The '''Teatro San Benedetto''' was a theatre in [[Venice]], particularly prominent in the operatic life of the city in the 18th and early 19th centuries. It saw the premieres of over 140 [[operas]], including Rossini's ''[[L'italiana in Algeri]]'', and was the theatre of choice for the presentation of ''[[opera seria]]'' until [[La Fenice]] was built in 1792.
==History== The small, elegant theatre was first constructed by [[Grimani|Michele Grimani]] on land owned by the [[House of Venier|Venier]] family. It was inaugurated on 26 December 1755 with a performance of [[Gioacchino Cocchi]]'s opera ''Zoe''. In 1766 the ownership of the San Benedetto passed from Grimani to a consortium of [[Patrician (post-Roman Europe)|patrician]] families in Venice who had been [[Box (theatre)|box]] holders at the theatre. The original design of the theatre was circular. However it was rebuilt in the traditional horseshoe shape following a fire in 1773.
In 1765 [[Vincenzo Galeotti]] who danced here from 1761 became the ballet master of the theatre and staged his first ballet here (at that time besides Galeotty and his wife Antonia there were two soloists and 16 corps de ballet dancers in the company). In 1772—1773 the ballet master of San Benedetto was [[Gasparo Angiolini]].
In 1782 Teatro San Benedetto hosted the ball in honour of Count and Countess De Nord, Russian prince [[Paul I of Russia|Pavel Petrovich]] and [[Maria Feodorovna (Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg)|his spouse]], visiting Venice.
In 1786 the owners' consortium had to cede the theatre to the Venier family following a lawsuit, and later went on to build La Fenice. The theatre then became the '''Teatro Venier''' (or Teatro Venier in San Benedetto).
In 1810, the ownership passed to the impresario Giovanni Gallo, and for a time it was known as the '''Teatro Gallo'''. His sons, who had inherited the theatre in 1847, renamed it '''Teatro Rossini''' in 1868 in honour of [[Gioachino Rossini]] whose operas ''[[L'italiana in Algeri]]'' and ''[[Eduardo e Cristina]]'' had premiered there earlier in the century, but by then its glory days as an opera house were over.
In 1937 the building was completely remodelled as a [[movie theater]], the Cinema Rossini, with a new facade by the Italian architect [[Carlo Scarpa]]. The cinema was closed in 2007 and will undergo restoration in 2010 in a project financed by the City of Venice.
==Sources== *Biblioteca Nazionale Braidense (Ufficio Ricerca Fondi Musicali), [http://www.urfm.braidense.it/documentazione/teatri_query.php?LuogoF=Venezia Luoghi di rappresentazione: Venezia]. Accessed 9 November 2009 (in Italian). *Comune di Venezia, [http://www.comune.venezia.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeBLOB.php/L/IT/IDPagina/26085 Ex Cinema Rossini, firmata la convenzione: ad aprile 2010 avvio dei lavori], press release of 22 April 2009. Accessed 9 November 2009 (in Italian). *Feldman, Martha, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xc-NFOnWQ0QC&pg=PA390&dq=teatro+san+benedetto++Venier&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=teatro%20san%20benedetto%20%20Venier&f=false ''Opera and sovereignty: transforming myths in eighteenth-century Italy''], University of Chicago Press, 2007, p. 390. {{ISBN|0-226-24113-0}} *Talbot, Michael, "Grimani", ''[[Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians|The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'' 2nd Edition, 2001. {{ISBN|0-333-60800-3}}
{{coord|45.4355|N|12.3325|E|source:wikidata|display=title}}

{{EngvarB|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox museum | name = Temple Bar Gallery and Studios | native_name = Gailearaí + Stiúideonna Bharra an Teampaill | native_name_lang = ga | logo = Temple_Bar_Gallery_and_Studios.gif | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Temple Bar Gallery and Studios.JPG | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = Ireland Central Dublin | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|53.345614|N|6.263723|W|type:landmark_region:IE|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1983}} | dissolved = | location = 5–9 [[Temple Bar, Dublin|Temple Bar]], [[Dublin 2]], Ireland | type = [[Art gallery]], [[Studio#Art_studio|Art studios]] | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = Jenny Haughton | director = Cliodhna Shaffrey | president = | ceo = | chairperson = Niall M. Kelly | curator = Rayne Booth | architect = McCullough Mulvin (1991 renovation) | historian = | owner = | publictransit = Stephen's Green [[Luas]] stop ([[Green Line (Luas)|Green Line]])
Wellington Quay bus stop | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|templebargallery.com}} | embedded = }} '''Temple Bar Gallery + Studios''' ('''TBG+S''') is located in the centre of [[Temple Bar, Dublin]]. ==Description== The organisation was founded in 1983 and the original studios and gallery were located in a former shirt factory. The current building is a mid-nineties structure that was built on the same site as part of the Temple Bar Architectural Framework Plan. The building is designed by Irish architects McCullough/Mulvin, who were one of the architectural practices involved in the Group 91 consortium that wrote the plan{{Cite web|url=http://archiseek.com/tag/group-91-architects/|title=Group '91 Architects Archives – Archiseek – Irish Architecture|website=Archiseek – Irish Architecture|dead-url=|access-date=5 February 2018}}. The building contains a [[contemporary art|contemporary visual art]] gallery and thirty artists studios.http://archiseek.com/2010/1994-temple-bar-gallery-studios/{{cite web |url=http://www.dublinculturetrail.ie/Venue.aspx?id=124bc173-a5de-4b8d-ab1d-7568d9a34b17 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=13 October 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908025902/http://www.dublinculturetrail.ie/Venue.aspx?id=124bc173-a5de-4b8d-ab1d-7568d9a34b17 |archivedate=8 September 2011 |df= }} Temple Bar Gallery + Studios is a limited company with charitable status that is artist-led. The voluntary Board is formally elected by the artist membership and comprises four artist members and five external professionals with different expertise and business acumen.{{Cite web|title = Board members :: Temple Bar Gallery + Studios :: Dublin Ireland.|url = http://www.templebargallery.com/info/about/board|website = ''templebargallery.com''|accessdate = 13 October 2015}} Temple Bar Gallery + Studios is a [[Non-profit organization|not for profit]] registered charity and receives its core funding from [[Arts Council of Ireland|the Arts Council of Ireland]]. TBG+ S is part of a residency exchange programme with HIAP International Residency Exchange Programme. The gallery has been chosen to receive funding of an exchange of a student in Finland. In 2008 the Finnish photographer [[Heli Rekula]] spent her year here.[http://www.finnish-institute.org.uk/en/articles/240-heli-rekula Irish/Finnish Artist Exchange Award 2008], Finnish Institute, 2008. Retrieved 14 May 2016 In 2013 a sculpture by Irish artist [[Garrett Phelan]] consisting of a metal arch bearing the words ''Our Union Only in Truth'' was added to the roof of the building. The commission was funded through an online crowd funding campaign.{{Cite web|title = Our Union Only in Truth: Garrett Phelan on Dublin's newest landmark|url = http://totallydublin.ie/arts-culture/our-union-only-in-truth-garrett-phelan-on-dublins-newest-landmark/|website = Totally Dublin|accessdate = 14 October 2015}}{{Cite web|title = Temple Bar Gallery + Studios – For Impact Learning {{!}} Newstream|url = http://www.businesstoarts.ie/newstream/blog/temple-bar-gallery-studios-for-impact-learning/|website = www.businesstoarts.ie|accessdate = 14 October 2015}} ==Selected past exhibitions== {{div col}} * Luke Fowler ''Pilgrimage from Scattered Points'' (March 2011) * Marjetica Potrč ''Florestania'' (October 2007) * Paul Nugent – ''Vigil'' (September 2007) * Group Exhibition Risa Sato, Eoin McHugh, Mark Garry ''Rapid Eye Movement'' (Summer 2007) * Matt Stokes ''Lost in the Rhythm'' – (January 2007) * First Irish solo exhibition and live event ''Sacred Selections'' – (February 2007) * Contemporary Organ recital with Matt Stokes, with organist Paul Ayers– Christchurch Cathedral, Dublin * Group Exhibition ''The Square Root of Drawing'' – (October 2006) * Lars Arrhenius – ''If Signs had Souls'' (July 2006) Elina Brotherus -''The New Painting'' (June 2006) * Group Exhibition ''A Moment in Time'' – (Dec 2005 – Jan 2006) Contemporary Painting at TBG+S. * Garrett Phelan – ''Black Brain Radio'' (January 2006) Mark Clare -'' Know Thyself'' (August 2005) * Ene-Liis Semper ''Licked Room & FF/REW plus Father & Shifting Focus by Mark Raidpere'' (March – April 2005) {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/0829/1224323181343.html Gallery says funding cut entitled it to lay off chief – The Irish Times – Wed, Aug 29, 2012] * [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2012/0727/1224320881294.html Summer Lightning strikes thrice – The Irish Times – Fri, Jul 27, 2012] * [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/0828/1224323095976.html Former chief executive of gallery claims unfair dismissal – The Irish Times – Tue, Aug 28, 2012] ==Further reading== * [http://www.frommers.com/destinations/dublin/A19776.html Review of Temple Bar Gallery and Studios and other gallery reviews in Dublin | Frommer's] ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070515143220/http://www.templebargallery.com/index.htm Official website] {{Museums and galleries in the Republic of Ireland}} [[Category:Art museums and galleries in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Arts in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Museums in Dublin (city)]] [[Category:Art galleries established in 1983]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Ireland]]

{{Expand French|La Mort de Polydoros|date=July 2018}} [[File:Tapisserie_La_mort_de_Polydoros.jpg|thumb|300px]] '''''The Death of Polydorus''''' is one of a set of seven tapestries showing a scene from the ''[[Iliad]]'' by Homer, here the death of Priam's son [[Polydorus (son of Priam)|Polydorus]] in book VI, link 290 and book XXIV, line 49. It was produced between 1623 and 1626 and is now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]].
It was commissioned from a Chinese manufacturer during the [[Ming dynasty]] or [[Qing dynasty]] by Francisco Mascarenhas, Portuguese governor of Macao from 1623 to 1626, since the medallions bear a female serpent and there is a lion a shield in each corner, the Mascarenhas family arms.
==Sources== *Archives du musée des Beaux-Arts de Lyon, catalogue no 1970/538
{{DEFAULTSORT:Death of Polydorus}} [[category:1620s works]] [[category:Tapestries]] [[category:Collections of the Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]]

{{Infobox theatre | name = Theatre Royal | image = Theatre Royal front facade, Manchester.jpg | image_size = 240px | image_alt = | caption = Theatre Royal front façade | address = | city = [[Manchester]] | country = England | designation = Grade II | coordinates = {{coord|53.4777|-2.2465|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = {{Plainlist| * John Gould Irwin & Francis Chester <small>(1845)</small> * [[Edward Salomon]] <small>(alteration in 1871)</small> }} | owner = Edwardian London | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = Victorian variety theatre | opened = {{Start date|1845}} | reopened = 1875, 1921, 1963, 1972, 1990 | yearsactive = 1845–1921 (as a theatre) | rebuilt s = | closed = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | patrons = | website = }} The '''Theatre Royal''' in Manchester, England, opened in 1845. Situated next to the [[Free Trade Hall]], it is the oldest surviving theatre in Manchester.<ref name="theatrestrust.org"/><ref name="ManchesterEveningNews20111103"/> It was commissioned by Mancunian businessman [[John Knowles (Manchester)|John Knowles]] who wanted a theatre venue in the city.
The Theatre Royal operated as a theatre from 1845 until 1921, when it closed in the face of growing competition from the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester|Palace Theatre]] and [[Manchester Opera House|Opera House]]. The building has since been converted numerous times for use as a cinema, bingo hall and nightclub. It has been unoccupied since 2009.
==Architecture== The theatre, which stands on an island site on the south side of Peter Street, is constructed in [[sandstone]] [[ashlar]]. It is in two storeys, with an attic, and is in [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] style. Around the building, between the upper storey and the attic, is a modillioned [[cornice]].<ref name=nhl>{{NHLE |num= 1246667|desc= Royale Club, Manchester|accessdate= 26 September 2010|mode=cs2|ps=none}}</ref> Its entrance front facing Peter Street is symmetrical with three [[bay (architecture)|bays]], the central bay being wider than the lateral bays. The central bay is in the form of a [[portico]], with [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] columns and [[pilaster]]s. Its [[entablature]] contains a central semicircular arch breaking through to the [[gable]]. Steps lead up to entrances in each bay. Above the central entrance is a [[pediment]]ed [[niche (architecture)|niche]] containing a statue of [[William Shakespeare]], which is based on the statue by [[Peter Scheemakers]] in [[Westminster Abbey]]. The lateral bays contain windows with balconies in the upper storey.{{sfn|Hartwell|Hyde|Pevsner|2004|p=322}} Along the sides of the theatre are alternating rectangular windows and panels, with a blank semicircular arch above each window. The interior of the theatre has been altered, but retains its 1875 gallery. The theatre was designated as a Grade II [[listed building]] on 3 October 1974.<ref name=nhl/> The authors of the ''[[Pevsner Architectural Guides|Buildings of England]]'' series describe it as a "splendid classical composition in stone, one of the best examples of theatre architecture surviving anywhere in England from the first half of the 19th century".{{sfn|Hartwell|Hyde|Pevsner|2004|p=322}} The [[Theatres Trust]] described it as "unique and architecturally significant", with the façade being "one of the finest examples of theatre architecture to have survived in Britain from the first half of the nineteenth century", stating that it influenced the design of the [[Royal Opera House, London]].<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
==Use as a Theatre== Manchester appears to have two previous Theatre Royals before the current building was constructed in 1845. The first opened in [[Spring Gardens, Manchester|Spring Gardens]] on 5 June 1775 and operated on that site until the expiration of the proprietors' lease in 1807.<ref name=Collectanea>{{citation |title=Collectanea relating to Manchester and its neighbourhood, at various periods |volume=2 |year=1867 |publisher=[[Chetham Society]] |page=59 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acI4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA58–59}}</ref>
The second Theatre Royal opened in Fountain Street on 12 July 1807 and was destroyed by fire on 7 March 1844.<ref name=Collectanea/> John Knowles took over the management of this second Theatre Royal some time before the fire, at a time when the [[theatre]] in Manchester was at its lowest ebb.<ref>'Index to the report from the Select Committee on Theatrical Licenses and Regulations', 1866, House of Commons Parliamentary Papers, vol. XVI.1, p. 217.</ref> Knowles set up a strong [[Stock company (acting)|stock company]] and proved himself a very capable, though somewhat authoritarian, [[theatre manager]]. However, following the 1844 fire the proprietors of the theatre in Fountain Street refused to rebuild it.
At a public dinner in his honour in July 1844, Knowles was presented a plate "in acknowledgement of his energetic and successful efforts to revive national drama in Manchester".<ref name="John Knowles 1844, p. 5">'Dinner to John Knowles, Jun, Esq', ''The Manchester Guardian'', 17 July 1844, p. 5</ref> Knowles told the gathering that if they could get no one else to build a theatre then he would do it himself. As a result, Knowles bought the [[patent rights]] and set about finding a site for the new theatre.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=18}} Knowles had always been an admirer of theatrical performances and he was anxious to see their renovation in this, his native town. He desired to see the revival of the legitimate drama, and the plays represented in a manner duly worthy of them.<ref name="John Knowles 1844, p. 5"/>
[[Image:(Former) Theatre Royal and (Former) Free Trade Hall, Manchester.jpg|thumb|left|Theatre Royal front facade on the left with the [[Free Trade Hall]].]] Knowles found a new site for his theatre on Peter Street. He demolished the Wellington Inn and Brogden's Horse Bazaar.{{sfn|Parkinson-Bailey|2000|p=87}} Knowles employed Francis Chester and John Gould Irwin as the [[architect]]s for his new theatre.{{sfn|Rudyard|Wyke|1994|p=57}} In preparation for the building of the new Theatre Royal, Knowles and Chester went to London and visited most of the metropolitan theatres, noting their areas, internal forms, [[Acoustics|acoustic capabilities]], etc.<ref>'The New Theatre Royal, Peter-Street', ''The Manchester Guardian'', 2 October 1844, p. 5</ref> With a cost of £23,000, the new Theatre Royal opened to an audience of 2,500.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=19}} Precautionary measures against fire were taken by placing a [[Water tank|tank]] on the roof capable of holding 20,000 gallons of water, which was connected by pipes to the stage and the [[green room]]. Its programme that night included [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber's]] ''[[Oberon (Weber)|Oberon]]'' overture, [[Douglas Jerrold]]'s "Time works wonders" and an elaborate [[ballet]] spectacle "The Court Ball in 1740". Knowles's schedule of productions was intensive – in one season there were 157 performances at which two and sometimes three plays were performed. The popularity of the theatre grew. [[Charles Dickens]], [[John Leech (caricaturist)|John Leech]] and [[George Cruikshank|George Cruickshank]]{{sfn|Parkinson-Bailey|2000|p=87}} were amongst notable people who appeared at the theatre. The theatre was dedicated to [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] and Knowles installed a [[Carrara marble]] statue of the playwright above the entrance. It was Manchester's finest outdoor statue.{{sfn|Rudyard|Wyke|1994|p=57}} In 1875, after years of success, Knowles severed his connections with the theatre, disposing of it to a [[limited company]] for £50,000.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=19}}
==Later use== In 1921 the theatre was converted to a [[Movie theater|cinema]] due to competition from the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester]] and the [[Manchester Opera House]]. In 1972 the theatre became a [[bingo hall]], then a [[nightclub]] in 1978,<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" /> at which point various lighting bridges and rigs were added.<ref name="theatrestrust.org" /> It was known successively as the "Discotheque Royale", Infinity then M2 and finally a rename and rebrand to Coliseum due to the trouble caused by the clientele it attracted. The nightclub closed in 2009.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
In 2008 a {{convert|118|m|ft|abbr=on}} 28-storey office and retail tower was proposed, called "Theatre Royal Tower", that would be connected to the back of the original theatre. It was designed by [[Stephenson Bell]] with [[The Benmore Group]] as the developer.<ref name="skyscraper" />
It was announced in 2011 by owners Benmore that the Theatre Royal would receive a £2 million refurbishment to convert the building into a live music venue.<ref name="ManchesterEveningNews20111103">{{cite news |title=Theatre Royal to become live music venue – with £2m refurb |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/business/s/1463880_theatre-royal-to-become-live-music-venue---with-2m-refurb |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> Plans to convert the building into a hotel and live music venue never came about.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
Despite the promise of investment, Benmore sold the building in November 2012.<ref name="MC_21Nov12" /> It was purchased by the [[Edwardian Group]], who owned the [[Radisson Blu]] Edwardian hotel adjacent to the theatre in the [[Free Trade Hall]].<ref name="MEN_20Nov12" /> The building could potentially be restored as a theatre or banqueting hall as a complimentary extension for the hotel.<ref name="MC_21Nov12" />
{{Asof|December 2016}} the building remains unused, with the Edwardian Group carrying out feasibility studies for the building. [[Theatres Trust]] has placed the building on its "Theatre Buildings At Risk" reigster.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
The 1845 exterior façade is virtually intact,<ref name="theatrestrust.org" /> and the building retains the balcony from 1875.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} [[Theatres Trust]] has said that the internal conversions for its past usage in various guises appear to have obscured – rather than destroyed  – the interior. The Trust classify the original interior work as "restorable as a theatre".<ref name="theatrestrust.org" />
==See also== {{Portal|Greater Manchester}} *[[Listed buildings in Manchester-M2]]
==References== {{commonscat|Theatre Royal, Manchester}} '''Notes''' {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="skyscraper">{{Cite web |title=Theatre Royal Tower |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=5574 |work=skyscrapernews.com |date=15 May 2008 |accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> <ref name="theatrestrust.org">{{cite web |title=Theatre Royal (Manchester) |url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/604-theatre-royal-manchester |publisher=Theatre Trust |accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> <ref name="MEN_20Nov12">{{cite news |title=Manchester Theatre Royal acquired by hotelier Edwardian Group |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/property/manchester-theatre-royal-acquired-by-hotelier-697282 |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date=20 November 2012}}</ref> <ref name="MC_21Nov12">{{Cite web |title=Radisson Edwardian To Extend Into The Theatre Royal |url=http://www.manchesterconfidential.co.uk/property-and-business/radisson-edwardian-to-extend-into-the-theatre-royal |work=Manchester Confidential |date=21 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-22}}</ref> <ref name="MEN_8Dec16">{{cite news | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/manchesters-oldest-theatre-bought-developer-12289920 | title=Manchester's oldest theatre was bought by a developer four years ago. But we still don't know what's going to happen to it... | publisher=[[Manchester Evening News]] | first=Andrew | last=Bardsley | date=8 December 2016}}</ref> }}
'''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} *{{cite book| last =Hartwell | first =Clare | authorlink = | last2 = Hyde | first2 = Matthew | author2-link =| last3 = Pevsner | first3 = Nikolaus | author3-link = Nikolaus Pevsner | series= The Buildings of England| title =Lancashire: Manchester and the South-East |edition= | publisher =[[Yale University Press]] | year =2004 | location =New Haven and London | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =0-300-10583-5 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Manchester Central Library |title=Men and Women of Manchester |year=1979 |publisher=William Morris Press |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Parkinson-Bailey |first=J. J. |title=Manchester: An Architectural History |year=2000 |publisher=Manchester University Press |isbn=978-0-7190-5606-2 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Rudyard |first1=Nigel |last2=Wyke |first2=Terry |title=Manchester Theatres |year=1994 |publisher=Bibliography of North West England |isbn=0-947969-18-7 |ref=harv}} {{refend}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Urban Wolf | genre = [[Science fiction]] [[Thriller (genre)|Thriller]] | creator = [[Laurent Touil-Tartour]] | director = [[Laurent Touil-Tartour]] | starring = [[Vincent Sze]] | composer = [[Thierry Caroubi]] | country = France / United States | language = English | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 15 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Napoleon Premiere | producer = [[Laurent Touil-Tartour]] | distributor = [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] | location = Paris | camera = [[Yves Dahan]] | runtime = 58 mn | network = [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Crackle (company)|Crackle]] | picture_format = 16/9 | audio_format = 5.1 Dolby Digital | first_run = Comic-Con 2009, San Diego | first_aired = May 13, 2010 on Sony's www.crackle.com | website = http://www.urbanwolf.com }} '''''Urban Wolf''''' is an award-winning online non-verbal drama series, with 15 webisodes of 4 minutes long each.
The movie was written, produced and directed by [[Laurent Touil-Tartour]].<ref>http://filmnewsbriefs.com/2009/12/fnb-innovators-laurent-tartour/</ref>
The world premiere and first public screening of the show took place at [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] 2009, in San Diego.
In 2009, at the 4th Annual Los Angeles [[ITVFest (Independent Television Festival)|Independent Television Festival]] ''Urban Wolf'' won the Award for Best Drama.<ref name="itvfest">{{cite web |url=http://itvfest.org/ |title=The 2009 ITVFest winners are... }}</ref> And in 2011, during the 15th Annual [[Webby Award]]s ''Urban Wolf'' won the People's Voice Award for Best Drama.<ref name="webbys">{{cite web |url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=97&season=15#film_drama |title=Urban Wolf winner of the Best Drama Webby Awards 2011 |access-date=2011-04-14 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5xvYAKEsL?url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=97&season=15#film_drama |archive-date=2011-04-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> It also has been selected for the 2009 [[American Film Institute|AFI]] DigiFest by the [[American Film Institute]] as "one of the most compelling example of new media storytelling".<ref name="afi">{{cite web |url=http://www.afi.com/Education/dcl/ |title=AFI DigiFest Most Compelling Films of 2009}}</ref>
On March 31, 2010, [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] officially announces a groundbreaking worldwide distribution deal for the series.<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cracklecom-launches-acclaimed-international-suspense-web-series-urban-wolf-89626007.html</ref> The show premiered on Sony Pictures Entertainment owned [[Crackle (company)|Crackle]] on May 13, 2010.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2010/03/urban-wolf/ | work=Wired | first=Hugh | last=Hart | title=Spy Thriller Urban Wolf Crackles With Tension (But Without Words) | date=March 31, 2010}}</ref> Then Sony Pictures syndicated the series in a multi-platform footprint including: [[YouTube]], [[hulu]], the [[PlayStation Network]], [[Google TV]], the [[Bravia (brand)|Bravia]] Network, [[Animax]], [[AXN]], [[AT&T]], [[Sprint Nextel|Sprint]], etc.
On October 19, 2012, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] releases an exclusive and innovative mobile app edition of Urban Wolf available on its 172 iTunes App Stores worldwide for [[iPhone]], [[iPod Touch]] and [[iPad]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/urban-wolf/id558781954?mt=8 | work=Apple | title=Apple presents Urban Wolf | date=October 19, 2012}}</ref> The Urban Wolf app edition features the entire 15 episodes of the series in HD and also offers an outstanding wealth of exclusive bonus feature to the next-gen format with in-depth background information. These extra materials function similarly to the extras section on a DVD box set.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theappside.com/2012/10/22/webby-winning-series-urban-wolf-comes-to-ios/ | work=The AppSide | title=Webby-winning series Urban Wolf comes to iOS | date=October 22, 2012}}</ref>
==Plot==
===Season 1 (2009)=== The plot focuses mainly on an American tourist freshly landed at Paris airport in France who is pursued and terrorized by a malevolent security camera operator.
==Awards and nominations==
===Awards=== * 2011 [[Webby Award]] – Best Drama Award Winner of the 15th Annual Webby People’s Voice Awards.<ref name="webbys"/> * 2009 [[ITVFest (Independent Television Festival)|Independent Television Festival]] – Best Drama Award Winner.<ref name="itvfest"/> * 2009 [[Dragon*Con]] Independent Film Festival – Staff Picks Award Winner.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmfest.dragoncon.org/filmfest09awards.htm |title=2009 Dragon*Con Awards Winners}}</ref>
===Nominations=== * 2009 [[American Film Institute]] DigiFest – Nominated as "Most Innovative Digital Media Production".<ref name="afi"/> * 2010 [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] - [[MIT Media Lab]] - Center for Future Storytelling - Official Selection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.media.mit.edu/research/center-future-storytelling |title=Urban Wolf at the MIT Media Lab}}</ref> * 2011 [[Webby Award]] – Nominated for "Best Drama" for both Webby Award and People's Voice Award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=97&season=15#film_drama |title=Urban Wolf nominated for Best Drama at The Webby Awards 2011 |access-date=2011-04-14 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5xvYAKEsL?url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=97&season=15#film_drama |archive-date=2011-04-14 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Honorees=== * 2011 [[Webby Award]] – Official Honoree for "Best Individual Performance" at the 15th Annual Webby Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current_honorees.php?media_id=97&category_id=695&season=15 |title=Urban Wolf distinguished as an Official Honoree for "Best Individual Performance at the Webby Awards 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== The series has received overwhelmingly enthusiastic critical reception. Journalist and critic Hugh Hart, writing for ''[[Wired Magazine]]'' noted: "[[Laurent Touil-Tartour]] exploits sharp edits, a driving score and spare cinematography to extract maximum tension and an handsomely filmed suspense drama.”<ref name="wired">{{cite news|author=Wired Magazine |url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2010/03/urban-wolf/ |title=Spy Thriller Urban Wolf Crackles With Tension (But Without Words) |publisher=wired.com |date= March 31, 2010|accessdate=2010-03-31}}</ref> Hugh Hart also enjoyed the usage of non-verbal storytelling: "Not a word gets spoken in Urban Wolf. But even without dialogue, French filmmaker Laurent Touil-Tartour has made an unusually sophisticated spy-tech thriller.”<ref name="wired"/>
Critic Jandy Stone Hardesty, in her review for Row Three, said that Touil-Tartour has “a nice flair for composition and a good sense of visual storytelling, he also knows how to do good twists and suggest things rather than spell them out, something I really appreciated.”<ref>{{cite news|author=Jandy Hardesty |url=http://www.rowthree.com/2010/05/16/urban-wolf-is-watching-you/ |title=Urban Wolf is watching you |publisher=rowthree.com |date= May 16, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-16}}</ref> William Bibbiani, in ''[[CraveOnline]]'', called it "an exciting little bit of filmmaking that deserves its notoriety and is worth howling about”,<ref>{{cite news|author=William Bibbiani |url=http://www.craveonline.com/tv/reviews/138846-urban-wolf-review/ |title=Urban Wolf review |publisher=craveonline.com |date= May 12, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> and Liz Shannon Miller writing in ''[[GigaOM]]'' wrote that "“Urban Wolf is a gripping thriller that stands out as proudly unique. Some of Wolf‘s execution might emulate classic 1970s thrillers, but the concept is pure 21st century, playing nimbly with issues of privacy and paranoia. When a director can make even the eating of a potato chip seem malevolent (as occurs in the yet-to-premiere episode 7), you know you’ve watching something special.”<ref>{{cite news|author=Liz Shannon Miller |url=http://gigaom.com/video/urban-wolf-a-near-perfect-21st-century-thriller/ |title=Urban Wolf a Near-Perfect 21st Century Thriller |publisher=gigaom.com |date= May 13, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-13}}</ref>
Reviewing it for the ''[[Mingle Media TV Network]]'', journalist Kristyn Burtt wrote: "The reason this series stands out amongst the pack is its cinematic feel and the utilization of mise en scene. You don't hear the main character utter a word until Episode 7, and boy, is it effective.”<ref>{{cite news|author=Kristyn Burtt |url=http://redcarpetcloset.blogspot.com/2010/05/i-came-upon-this-series-at-last-years.html |title=Urban Wolf behind the scenes |publisher=The Web Files |date= May 17, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref>
Awarding the film a five out of five star rating, Feo Amante's film critic E.C.McMullen Jr. wrote: "The tension from episode to episode is incredible and Laurent just keeps ramping it up. With its beautiful settings (shot in Paris, France), excellent cinematography, and super tight, witty action, this could very well define the future of online cinema. I'm not kidding! URBAN WOLF is a Turbo Thrust Cat and Mouse Thriller with a V8 engine!”<ref>{{cite news|author=E.C.McMullen Jr. |url=http://www.feoamante.com/Movies/STU/urban_wolf.html/ |title=Urban Wolf review |publisher=feoamante.com |date= May 14, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref>
==Characters and cast==
===Urban Wolf=== Actor [[Vincent Sze]] plays the role of Justin Case.
==References== {{Reflist|2}} ;Further Reading [http://filmnewsbriefs.com/2009/12/fnb-innovators-laurent-tartour/ Interview with Laurent Touil-Tartour]
*<cite>{{cite web|url=http://www.webseriesnetwork.com/profiles/blogs/laurent-touiltartours-urban|title=Laurent Touil-Tartour's 'Urban Wolf' Could Change Web Series Forever|last=Mbariket|first=Rich|date=April 22, 2010 |publisher=[[The Web Series Network]]}}</cite> *<cite>{{cite web|url=http://www.feoamante.com/Movies/STU/urban_wolf.html|title=URBAN WOLF could very well define the future of online cinema. I'm not kidding! URBAN WOLF is a Turbo Thrust Cat and Mouse Thriller with a V8 engine!|last=Amante|first=Feo|date=April 28, 2010 |publisher=[[Feo Amante]]}}</cite> *<cite>{{cite web|url=http://www.eguiders.com/video/urban-wolf|title=Urban Wolf may become the first successful international thriller web series|last=Roth|first=Melissa|date=August 6, 2009 |publisher=[[eGuiders]]}}</cite> *<cite>{{cite web|url=http://www.feoamante.com/Cons/ComicCon_2009/index.html|title=I'm putting my money on a new webseries called URBAN WOLF|last=Amante |first=Feo |date=July 25, 2009 |publisher=[[Feo Amante]]}}</cite>
==External links== * [http://www.urbanwolf.com/ Urban Wolf's Homepage] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y3Zvu0vbubk Urban Wolf on YouTube] * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1458696/ Internet Movie Database] * [http://itvfest.bside.com/2009/films/urbanwolf_itvfest2009] on [[ITVFest (Independent Television Festival)|Independent Television Festival]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Advert5.jpg|thumb|alt=The Workington Opera House.|The Workington Opera House - Pre 1927.]]
The '''Workington Opera House''', or ''The Opera'' as it was known, is a purpose built [[theatre]] located in Workington, Cumbria, England. Originally built as the Queen’s Jubilee Hall & Opera House it was gutted by [[fire]] in 1927 and rebuilt with a fine wide [[auditorium]], and Ornamental ceiling with seating for 1200. The theatre has good sightlines and a large stage and currently sits empty after its former use as a bingo hall ended in 2004.
==History== [[Image:Operahouse2010.jpg|thumb|alt=The Workington Opera House.|The Workington Opera House - 2010.]] The theatre was designed by T. L. Banks & Townsend and had a small [[auditorium]] with two [[balconies]] accommodating 1,130 people. The theatre was also equipped with a small [[Stage (theatre)|stage]] with a [[proscenium]] width of 11 metres, a depth of 9.14 metres and a grid height of 14 metres. An [[orchestra]] pit for 16 musicians was also included.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/OperaHouseWorkington.htm |title= The Opera House, Pow Street, Workington, Cumbria |publisher=arthurlloyd.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-04-02}}</ref>
*Other names: **Queen's Jubilee Hall *Dates: **Opened 1888. Date of first use not known. **1888 - Design/Construction: ***T.L. Banks & Townsend - Architect **1897-1900 - Alteration: reconstructed after [[explosion]] ([[architect]] unknown) **1927-1930 - Alteration: reconstructed after fire (architect unknown) **1963-1970 - Alteration: [[façade]] rebuilt (architect unknown)
==Current owners==
Graves (Cumberland) Ltd currently own the building and have planning permission for 5 years to replace the theatre with retail and residential units. Graves own many different assets across [[Cumbria]] including cinemas, bingo halls and in the past they owned and ran a number of theatres.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.companiesintheuk.co.uk/ltd/graves-(cumberland) |title= GRAVES (CUMBERLAND) LIMITED |publisher=Companies in the UK |date= |accessdate=2011-04-02}}</ref>
[[Image:SAVEworkingtonoperahouselogoSQ.png|thumb|alt=SAVE Workington Opera House.|SAVE Workington Opera House logo.]]
==The future of the theatre==
The Workington Opera House is now under threat of [[demolition]] to be replaced with [[retail unit]]s and [[Apartment|flats]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsandstar.co.uk/civic-trust-backs-plans-to-demolish-workington-s-opera-house-1.685438?referrerPath=home/2.1962 |title= Civic trust backs plans to demolish Workington's Opera House |publisher=News and Star |date= |accessdate=2010-04-06}}</ref> The ''Save Workington Opera House'' group are fighting to have this building made available to the town of [[Workington]] as a working civic theatre that the community can be proud of.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workingtonoperahouse.co.uk |title= Save Workington Opera House |publisher=Workington Opera House |date= |accessdate=2010-04-06}}</ref>
==Specifications== *Capacities: **Original: 1,330 **After 1950: 1,219 *Listings: **Grade not listed *Stage type: **[[Proscenium]] *Dimensions **Stage dimensions: ***Depth: 9.14m ***Proscenium width: 11m ***Height to grid: 14m ***[[Orchestra pit]]: Original, for 16 musicians<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/resources/theatres/show/2016-opera-house-workington |title= Opera House (Workington) |publisher=Theatres Trust |date= |accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref>
